THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL 
  VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT 
  AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Paul A. Gray, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
John M. Milling, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-552
Submitted October 1, 2004 â€“ Filed November 
  1, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Acting Chief Attorney Joseph L. Savitz, III, of the South Carolina 
  Office of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, 
  and Senior Assistant Attorney General Harold M. Coombs, Jr., all of Columbia; 
  and Solicitor Ralph E. Hoisington, of Charleston; for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Â Paul A. Gray was convicted of first-degree criminal sexual 
  conduct (CSC) with a minor and sentenced to eighteen years imprisonment.Â  Gray 
  was also convicted of performing a lewd act on a minor and sentenced to eight 
  years imprisonment, suspended upon the service of five years probation, to be 
  served consecutively with the other sentence.Â  He was acquitted of another CSC 
  charge.Â  He appeals, arguing the trial court erred in admitting expert testimony 
  concerning the victimâ€™s late reporting of the incident.Â  We affirm. 
FACTS
In 2001, the then eight-year-old 
  victim was living with her grandmother in McClellanville, South Carolina.Â  Loretta 
  Gray, Grayâ€™s mother, would baby-sit the victim everyday from the time the victim 
  got home from school until her grandmother came home from work.Â  The victim 
  would often come to Grayâ€™s house to drop off her books, walk to her grandmotherâ€™s 
  house to get some food or a change of clothing, and return to Grayâ€™s house until 
  her grandmother returned from work.Â  In April 2001, the victim went to stay 
  with her mother in North Charleston for spring break, and she told her that 
  Gray molested her.Â  Gray was indicted by the grand jury on two counts of CSC 
  with a minor and one count of performing a lewd act upon a minor.Â  
The victim testified at trial regarding several incidents occurring sometime 
  between January and April 2001.Â  According to the victim, Gray would often grab 
  her and either lie on top of her, put his hands down her underwear, or, on two 
  occasions, place his penis in her mouth in an attempt to force her to perform 
  oral sex on him.Â  The incidents occurred either at Grayâ€™s house or at the victimâ€™s 
  grandmotherâ€™s house.Â  The victim also testified that she defended herself from 
  Gray each time he demanded oral sex by biting him and by wielding a knife on 
  one occasion when he placed his hands down her pants.Â  The victim stated she 
  was scared to tell anyone about the incidents, but she finally felt safe enough 
  to tell her mother because she was not near Gray at the time.Â  
The State sought to present 
  the testimony of counselor Allison Rogers regarding how a delay in reporting 
  abuse is common in child abuse cases.Â  Gray moved to exclude her testimony, 
  and the trial court allowed an in camera examination of Rogers.Â  
  Rogers testified in camera that â€œdelayed disclosure,â€ which is the time 
  period between when abuse takes place and when the victim reports the abuse, 
  is common in child abuse cases.Â  Rogers stated children often delay disclosing 
  abuse because they are embarrassed or they are afraid of the repercussions.Â  
  Rogers also stated that children sometimes disclose with â€œtentative disclosureâ€ 
  in which they initially deny the abuse, tentatively disclose the abuse to test 
  adultsâ€™ reactions, and then fully disclose the abuse when they feel comfortable 
  that they are safe and will be believed.Â  Gray objected to the admission of 
  the behavioral testimony as more prejudicial than probative.Â  The trial court 
  denied the motion, finding the testimony was relevant and any prejudicial effect 
  was outweighed by the probative value.Â Â  
After a short break, Rogers 
  took the stand and repeated her testimony regarding delayed reporting in front 
  of the jury.Â  Gray did not object to her qualification as an expert witness.Â  
  Gray was acquitted of one count of CSC, convicted of one count of first-degree 
  CSC with a minor, and convicted of performing a lewd act on a minor.Â  He appeals. 

STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œThe question of whether to admit or exclude testimony of an expert witness 
  is within the discretion of the trial court.â€Â  State v. Weaverling, 337 
  S.C. 460, 474, 523 S.E.2d 787, 794 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  The trial courtâ€™s ruling 
  on the admission of expert testimony will not be excluded absent an abuse of 
  discretion amounting to an error of law.Â  Id.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Gray argues the trial court erred in admitting the testimony regarding delayed 
  reporting since the probative value was substantially outweighed by the prejudicial 
  effect.Â  We disagree.
Initially, the State argues this issue is not preserved for review.Â  Relying 
  on State v. Schumpert, 312 S.C. 502, 435 S.E.2d 859 (1993), the State 
  argues that Gray failed to renew his objection when Rogers testified in front 
  of the jury, and, thus, he never obtained a final ruling on the matter.Â  Generally, 
  a pre-trial ruling on the admission of evidence is not considered final and 
  a party must renew his objection at the time the evidence is admitted.Â  See 
  Schumpert, 312 S.C. at 507, 435 S.E.2d at 862 (â€œUnless an objection is 
  made at the time the evidence is offered and a final ruling made, the issue 
  is not preserved for review.â€).Â  However, where the motion is ruled on immediately 
  prior to the introduction of the evidence in question and no other testimony 
  is presented to provide a basis for the trial court to change its ruling, the 
  ruling is final and no further objection is necessary.Â  State v. Tufts, 
  355 S.C. 493, 497, 585 S.E.2d 523, 525 (Ct. App. 2003), cert. denied 
  (June 24, 2004); Samples v. Mitchell, 329 S.C. 105, 109, 495 S.E.2d 213, 
  215 (Ct. App. 1997); State v. Mueller, 319 S.C. 266, 268-69, 460 S.E.2d 
  409, 410-11 (Ct. App. 1995).Â  In this case, the parties argued the motion during 
  the trial, Rogersâ€™ testimony was taken in camera, and the trial court 
  ruled the testimony was admissible.Â  Under these facts, it is clear the trial 
  court made a final ruling on the matter and it is preserved for review.
As to the merits, Gray argues the behavioral evidence presented was prejudicial 
  because â€œthe scientific community believes late reporting actually corroborates 
  a belatedly told story of sexual molestation.â€Â  In Schumpert, our supreme 
  court held that â€œexpert testimony and behavioral evidence are admissible as 
  rape trauma evidence to prove a sexual offense occurred where the probative 
  value of such evidence outweighs its prejudicial effect.â€Â  Schumpert, 
  312 S.C. at 506, 435 S.E.2d at 862.Â  Similarly, this court held that expert 
  testimony regarding behavioral characteristics of sexual assault victims was 
  admissible: â€œSuch testimony is relevant and helpful in explaining to the jury 
  the typical behavior patterns of adolescent victims of sexual assault. . . . 
  It assists the jury in understanding some of the aspects of the behavior of 
  victims and provides insight into the sexually abused childâ€™s often strange 
  demeanor.â€Â  Weaverling, 337 S.C. at 475, 523 S.E.2d at 794 (citation 
  omitted).Â  
Rogersâ€™ testimony in the present case explained to the jury that child victims 
  of sexual assault often delay reporting abuse until they are assured that adults 
  will take them seriously and they will be protected.Â  The victim also testified 
  that she did not reveal the abuse to her mother until she was away from Gray.Â  
  Rogersâ€™ testimony explained the victimâ€™s reaction, and it was thus more probative 
  than prejudicial in this instance.Â  We find the trial court did not abuse its 
  discretion. 
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, Grayâ€™s convictions and sentences are 
AFFIRMED. [1] Â  
STILWELL, BEATTY, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

 
   [1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: Excitement Video, Inc. v. Board of Zoning Appeals
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO 
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY 
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Excitement Video, Inc., Appellant,
v.
Board of Zoning Appeals, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
Steven H. John, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-553
Submitted October 1, 2004 â€“ Filed November 1, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
H. Louis Sirkin, of Cincinnati and Jill Wright Fennel, of Myrtle Beach, for 
  Appellant.
John L. Weaver, of Conway, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Excitement Video, Inc. appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order 
  affirming the Horry County Board of Zoning Appealsâ€™ denial of a certificate 
  of zoning compliance.Â  We affirm [1] . 
FACTS
On May 25, 2001, Horry County Business License manager Roddy Dickenson notified 
  Excitement by letter that Horry County was denying its request for the renewal 
  of its business license.Â  The stated reason was that Excitement was in violation 
  of an Horry County ordinance that prohibited the issuance of adult entertainment 
  establishment licenses pursuant to the Adult Entertainment Moratorium.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
Additionally, the zoning administrator declined to issue Excitement a certificate 
  of zoning compliance for the business.Â  The basis of the denial was that Excitementâ€™s 
  location was within 2000 feet of a residential area and a church in violation 
  of Horry County Code of Ordinances, Appendix B, section 526.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
Excitement appealed the zoning administratorâ€™s decision to the Board of Zoning 
  Appeals.Â  At the hearing, the only testimony offered was that of the zoning 
  administrator.Â  The administrator testified that while on a routine fire inspection, 
  he observed that Excitement was operating as an adult entertainment establishment.Â  
  He based his assessment on the fact that â€œ99 percent of the shelf and wall displays 
  were Triple XXX videos and anatomically correct adult products used for sexual 
  stimulation. . . . [O]ther than the bathrooms and a drink vending area, adult 
  videos and adult products consumed the gross floor area of the store.â€Â  Horry 
  County Code of Ordinances, Appendix B, section 526.3 defines an â€œAdult Video 
  Storeâ€ as any enterprise deriving more than fifty percent of its gross revenues 
  from adult materials. [2] Â  The 
  administrator also testified that Excitement did not meet the spacing requirement 
  of 2000 feet from a residential use or a church.Â  
Excitement put forth the argument that natural vegetation created a â€œbuffer 
  zoneâ€ that insulated the business from the view of both the church and the residential 
  area.Â  However, the administrator testified Excitement was not in literal compliance 
  with the zoning ordinance, which requires that measurements be taken from one 
  point to another in a straight line.Â  Measurements indicated Excitement was 
  located 1825 feet from a church and 1598 feet from a residential area.Â  
After consideration of the matter, the Board denied the appeal based upon specific 
  findings that Excitementâ€™s business was an adult entertainment establishment 
  as defined in Horry County Zoning Ordinance section 526.3 and it was within 
  2000 feet of a residential area and a church.Â  
Excitement appealed to the circuit court.Â  In addition to the grounds raised 
  in its petition for review, Excitement argued to the circuit court that it did 
  not receive a fair hearing before the Board in violation of its due process 
  rights.Â  The circuit court requested briefs from both sides on the due process 
  issue.Â  After considering the briefs, the circuit court affirmed the Boardâ€™s 
  decision.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The South Carolina Local Government Comprehensive Planning Enabling Act (Zoning 
  Enabling Act) sets forth the standard of review for appeals from local zoning 
  boards of appeal:Â  â€œThe findings of fact by the board of appeals shall be treated 
  in the same manner as a finding of fact by a jury . . . .â€ S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 
  6-29-840 (2004).Â  â€œIn determining the questions presented by the appeal, the 
  court must determine only whether the decision of the board is correct as a 
  matter of law.â€Â  Id.Â  Thus, the factual findings of the zoning board 
  will not be disturbed unless there is no evidence in the record to support its 
  decision.Â  Heilker v. Zoning Bd. of Appeals for the City of Beaufort, 
  346 S.C. 401, 406, 552 S.E.2d 42, 45Â  (Ct. App. 2001).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Due Process
Excitement argues that it did not receive a fair hearing 
  before the Board of Zoning Appeals because the Board did not provide it with 
  a meaningful opportunity to cross examine adverse witnesses, thereby depriving 
  Excitement of its due process rights.Â  We disagree. 
â€œThe fundamental requirement of due process is the opportunity to be heard 
  at a meaningful time and in a meaningful manner.â€Â  South Carolina Depâ€™t of 
  Soc. Servs. v. Beeks, 325 S.C. 243, 246, 481 S.E.2d 703, 705 (1997).Â  â€œDue 
  process is flexible and calls for such procedural protections as the particular 
  situation demands.â€Â  Stono River Envtl. Protection Assâ€™n v. South Carolina 
  Depâ€™t of Health and Envtl. Control, 305 S.C. 90, 94, 406 S.E.2d 340, 342 
  (1991).
Excitement contends it did not receive a fair hearing because 
  the chairman of the Board interrupted its attorney as he attempted to cross-examine 
  the zoning administrator on the presence of a buffer between the business and 
  nearby church and residences.Â  Our review of the record reveals that the Chairman 
  interrupted Excitementâ€™s attorneyâ€™s cross-examination of the zoning administrator 
  only to inform him that the administratorâ€™s determination as to the adequacy 
  of a buffer was not relevant as he was limited to enforcing the zoning ordinance 
  as written.Â  Excitementâ€™s attorney was in fact able to question the administrator 
  about the existence of vegetation providing a buffer and receive the administratorâ€™s 
  answers.Â  Excitement was also allowed to submit into evidence pictures of the 
  alleged buffer and make its argument on this issue.Â  In addition, Excitement 
  was able to question the administrator on the basis for his determination that 
  the business was in violation of the ordinance by having more than fifty percent 
  of its revenue derived from the sale of adult products and to present its argument 
  that the burden was on the administrator to prove this violation.Â  
Near the conclusion of the hearing, the following exchange 
  occurred between the Chairman and Excitementâ€™s attorney:

[Attorney]:Â  Iâ€™ve got it in the record, and Iâ€™m done.Â  Thatâ€™s 
  all I wanted to do.
The Chairman:Â  Okay.Â 
[Attorney]:Â  Thatâ€™s all I wanted to do.Â  Thank you.Â  Weâ€™ll rest 
  with the record as it is.Â 
The Chairman:Â  Okay. Do we have any other statement from you?
[Attorney]:Â  No. I believe I have created my record.Â  I canâ€™t argue the 
  measurements.Â 

It is clear from the record that Excitement was given sufficient opportunity 
  to present its case.Â  It never complained about the interruptions or asked for 
  the opportunity to question the witness further.Â  In addition, Excitement failed 
  to present evidence or make further argument when given the opportunity.Â  If 
  Excitementâ€™s attorney thought that the hearing was conducted in a manner that 
  did not present Excitement with the opportunity to be heard in a meaningful 
  manner in violation of the dictates of due process, then he should have made 
  a statement at that time. Â 
We agree with the circuit court that Excitement has failed to prove a violation 
  of its right to due process.Â  

II.Â  Buffer Zone
Excitement next argues that the circuit court erred when it determined that 
  the secondary effects of adult businesses were not negated by the existence 
  of a buffer between Excitement and the church and the residential area.Â  We 
  disagree.Â  
On appeal, Excitement contends:Â  â€œ[A] local government seeking to justify its 
  zoning restrictions on the basis of the secondary effects doctrine need demonstrate:Â  
  (1) that the drafters of the ordinance relied upon studies of secondary effects, 
  and (2) that a majority of the members of the voting body received some information 
  about the secondary effects.â€Â  Excitement, however, failed to raise any argument 
  about a lack of evidence justifying Horry Countyâ€™s adult business zoning ordinances 
  to the Board or the circuit court.Â  Accordingly, this argument is not properly 
  before this court.Â  See Burton v. County of Abbeville, 312 S.C. 
  359, 361, 440 S.E.2d 396, 397 (Ct. App. 1994) (stating issue was not preserved 
  for appeal where neither county zoning board of appeals nor circuit court addressed 
  issue and appellant did not seek a ruling by a post-trial motion).
Excitement also asserts the â€œnatural barrier mitigates any negative impacts 
  upon the surrounding community and therefore undercuts the Countyâ€™s ability 
  to regulate Excitement Videoâ€™s location.â€Â  The Board and circuit court relied 
  on Restaurant Row Assocs. v. Horry County in rejecting this assertion. 
  335 S.C. 209, 516 S.E. 2d 442 (1999).Â  We agree that Restaurant Row is 
  directly on point.Â  In Restaurant Row, Thee DollHouse, an adult entertainment 
  business located in Horry County, challenged the Boardâ€™s denial of their request 
  for a variance from the provisions of Horry County zoning plan which at the 
  time prohibited the location of an adult entertainment establishment within 
  500 feet of a residential district.Â  Thee DollHouse argued that the natural 
  barrier of the Atlantic Intracoastal Waterway created a buffer zone between 
  its location and the residential area and thereby prevented the possibility 
  of any negative secondary effects from arising.Â  Id. at 220, 516 S.E.2d 
  at 448.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
Our supreme court found the argument unconvincing.Â  The court explained that 
  zoning distance measurements must be done â€œas the crow fliesâ€ rather than based 
  on the actual terrain that must be crossed.Â  Id. at 221, 516 S.E.2d at 
  448.Â  The court noted that according to testimony in front of the Board, a bridge 
  was being constructed across the Atlantic Intracoastal Waterway very near Thee 
  DollHouse and a nearby tram ferried persons across the Intracoastal Waterway.Â  
  The court held:Â  â€œWhat this testimony shows is that even though there may be 
  a natural barrier now, there may be a bridge in the future.Â  . . . [Z]oning 
  is not only concerned about present conditions, but focuses on the future as 
  well.â€ Id. at 221, 516 S.E.2d at 448-49.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
In the present case, Excitement argues that a strip of natural vegetation provides 
  an adequate natural buffer.Â  As the Board recognized, the natural vegetation 
  that currently exists could disappear at any time whether through a natural 
  occurrence or through clearance for development.Â  We find no error in the Boardâ€™s 
  determination that Excitement is in violation of Horry County Code of Ordinances, 
  Appendix B, section 526. 
CONCLUSION
Based upon the foregoing reasoning, the order of the circuit court is 
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., HUFF and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.Â 


 
   [1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.

 
   [2]  When Excitement procured its original business 
    license, it did not meet this definition of â€œAdult Video Store.â€Â

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE 
  CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Patricia Fici, Respondent/Appellant,
v.
Karol Koon, Kerry Koon Stack, Century 21 Bob Capes Realtors, Inc., and 
        Francis Hipp, Defendants,
Of whom Karol Koon and Kerry Koon Stack are the,
Appellant/Respondents,
And, Century 21 Bob Capes Realtors, Inc., and Francis Hipp are the,
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Joseph M.Â  Strickland, Master-in-Equity

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-554
Submitted October 1, 2004 â€“ Filed November 3, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Jean Perrin Derrick, 
  of Lexington, for Appellant-Respondents.
Catharine H. Garbee Griffin, 
  of Columbia, for Respondents.
William E. Booth, III, 
  of Columbia, for Respondent-Appellant.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Patricia Fici (â€œFiciâ€) brought this action against Karol 
  Koon and Kerry Koon Stack (collectively referred to as â€œ the Koonsâ€) seeking 
  specific performance of a contract to sell 30 acres of property and to cancel 
  restrictive covenants placed on the property.Â  Both Fici and the Koons sought 
  attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  The master found the contract violated the statute of frauds, 
  declined to address the restrictive covenants, and denied all partiesâ€™ attorneyâ€™s 
  fee requests.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Fici sought land in Columbia upon which to build a home.Â  Francis Hipp (â€œHippâ€) 
  acted as her broker in the search for suitable property.Â  The Koons inherited 
  fifty acres of land from their father.Â  They wanted to keep 10-acres each and 
  sell the remaining 30-acres to help finance the construction of homes on their 
  parcels.Â Â Â  
The parties signed a contract for sale using a standard realtorâ€™s sales contract.Â  
  The Koonsâ€™ intentions leading up to the contract were to place restrictions 
  on the property to keep it from being subdivided or sold for use in an adjacent 
  subdivision.Â  However, no restrictive covenants were placed on the property 
  prior to the signing of the contract.
The contract called for the property lines to be determined upon agreement 
  of the parties.Â  Specifically, it called for the Koons as sellers to have a 
  survey done to determine the property lines.Â  Handwritten and then initialed 
  by all three parties was the notation:Â  â€œPurchaser and Seller to agree on location 
  of property lines.â€Â  
On March 9, 2001, the parties met at the property and with the help of a surveyor, 
  roughed in some boundary lines by hand on an older plat of the property.Â  The 
  parties each signed the plat over their portion of the property.Â  This plat 
  included the language:Â  â€œSurvey to be performed week of March 12 by CTH Surveyors.â€Â  
  Fici agreed this plat did not represent a designation of the final boundaries.Â  

The surveyor faxed the resulting plat to the parties on March 14, 2001.Â  The 
  Koons, however, were not satisfied with the division of the property, mainly 
  due to the location of the access road.Â  A second plat, which was also unsatisfactory, 
  was produced on March 16, 2001.Â  A third and final plat was produced on March 
  19, 2001 and sent to Hipp on March 21, 2001.Â Â Â  
After receiving the plat on March 21, 2001, Hipp took the written restrictions 
  and the plat and recorded them at the Office of the Register of Deeds for Richland 
  County.Â  Hipp, Fici, her counsel, and several other members of Hippâ€™s real estate 
  brokerage were present at a meeting regarding the property.Â  Hipp showed Fici 
  a copy of the updated plat.Â  Fici signed the plat:Â  â€œProperty lines for tract 
  3 are ok for me â€“ Pat Fici 3/22/01.â€Â Â Â  The Koons never signed the plat.
Fici brought this action when the Koons refused to cancel the filed restrictive 
  covenants on the property.Â  She sought specific performance of the contract, 
  rescission of the restrictive covenants, damages for breach of fiduciary duty 
  against Hipp and the brokerage, and damages for tortuous interference with a 
  contract. [1]   
The circuit court granted Fici a temporary injunction prohibiting the Koons 
  from disposing of the property and referred the specific performance action 
  to a master-in-equity while reserving the claims for damages for trial by jury.Â  
  The circuit court also required Fici to post a bond, by depositing the purchase 
  amount into an account maintained by her at Wachovia Bank.Â  Fici was â€œrestrained 
  and prohibited from withdrawing any funds from the investment account or causing 
  any funds to be taken out of the investment account during the pendancy of this 
  action.â€Â  
The Koons answered by making a general denial of the claims.Â  During trial, 
  the Koons moved to amend their answer to specifically allege the affirmative 
  defense of the Statute of Frauds.Â  The master allowed the Koons to amend their 
  Answer because â€œthis amendment conforms with evidence already in the record.â€Â  

The master concluded the contract was too indefinite in its description of 
  the property to meet the requirements of the Statute of Frauds.Â  Additionally, 
  the master concluded the parties signed no other writings detailing the boundaries 
  of the property being sold to Fici.Â  Thus, the master denied Ficiâ€™s request 
  for specific performance.Â  
The Koons filed a motion for costs and attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Â Â Subsequently, 
  they filed a Contempt Complaint and a Rule to Show Cause seeking to hold Fici 
  in contempt for withdrawing the money held at Wachovia prior to termination 
  of the action.Â  The master concluded the Koons were not entitled to attorneyâ€™s 
  fees and declined to hold Fici in contempt.
ISSUES ON APPEAL

  
    
      
        I.  
        Did the master err in allowing the Koons to amend 
  their Answer to specifically allege the Statute of Frauds as an affirmative 
  defense?
      
      
        II.
         Did the master err in failing to award specific performance of 
  the contract?
      
      
        III. 
         Did the master err in failing to award either party attorneyâ€™s 
  fees?
      
    
  

STANDARD OF REVIEW
An action for specific 
  performance lies in equity.Â  See Ingram v. Kaseyâ€™s Assocs., 340 
  S.C. 98, 105, 531 S.E.2d 287, 290 (2000) (citing Collier v. Green, 244 
  S.C. 367, 137 S.E.2d 277 (1964)); see also Satcher v. Satcher, 
  351 S.C. 477, 482, 570 S.E.2d 535, 538 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  â€œOur scope of review 
  for a case heard by a Master-in-Equity who enters a final judgment is the same 
  as that for review of a case heard by a circuit court without a jury.â€Â  Tiger, 
  Inc. v. Fisher Agro, Inc., 301 S.C. 229, 237, 391 S.E.2d 538, 543 (1989).Â  
  This court may review the evidence to determine facts in accordance with our 
  own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  See Townes Assocs. 
  Ltd. v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 86, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775 (1976).Â  
  â€œWhile this permits us a broad scope of review, we do not disregard the findings 
  of the Master, who saw and heard the witnesses and was in a better position 
  to evaluate their credibility.â€Â  Tiger, 301 S.C. at 237, 391 S.E.2d at 
  543.Â Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Motion 
  to Amend
Fici contends the master erred in allowing the Koons to amend their Answer 
  to specifically assert the Statute of Frauds as an affirmative defense.Â  We 
  disagree and find the amendment conformed to the evidence presented at trial.
Rule 15(b), SCRCP provides in pertinent part:

When issues not raised by the pleadings are tried by express or implied consent 
  of the parties, they shall be treated in all respects as if they had been raised 
  in the pleadings.Â  Such amendment of the pleadings as may be necessary to cause 
  them to conform to the evidence and to raise these issues may be made upon motion 
  of any party at any time, even after judgment; but failure so to amend does 
  not affect the result of the trial of these issues.Â  If evidence is objected 
  to at the trial on the ground that it is not within the issues made by the pleadings, 
  the court may allow the pleadings to be amended and shall do so freely when 
  the presentation of the merits of the action will be subserved thereby and the 
  objecting party fails to satisfy the court that the admission of such evidence 
  would prejudice him in maintaining his action or defense upon the merits.Â Â  


The decision whether to allow the amendment of pleadings to conform to the 
  evidence is left to the sound discretion of the trial court.Â  Kelly v. South 
  Carolina Farm Bureau Mut. Ins. Co., 316 S.C. 319, 323, 450 S.E.2d 59, 61 
  (Ct. App. 1994).Â  Amendments should be allowed if no prejudice occurs to the 
  opposing party.Â  Rule 15(b), SCRCP; Soil & Material Engâ€™rs, Inc. v. Folly 
  Assocs., 293 S.C. 498, 501, 361 S.E.2d 779, 781 (Ct. App. 1987).
Rule 15(b) covers two situations involving amendments to conform to the evidence.Â  
  â€œFirst, if an issue not raised by the pleadings is tried by express or implied 
  consent of the parties the court may permit amendment of the pleadings to reflect 
  the issue.Â  Second, if a party objects to the introduction of evidence as not 
  being within the pleadings the court may permit amendment of the pleadings subject 
  to a right to grant a continuance if necessary.â€Â  Sunvillas Homeowners Assâ€™n, 
  Inc. v. Square D Co., 301 S.C. 330, 334, 391 S.E.2d 868, 871 (Ct. App. 1990).Â  
  â€œExpress consent may be demonstrated by a stipulation but implied consent depends 
  on whether the parties recognized an issue not raised by the pleadings entered 
  the case during the trial.â€Â  Id. at 335, 391 S.E.2d at 871.
In the instant case, the parties both raised issues regarding the insufficient 
  description of the property.Â  The parties each discussed the relevancy of the 
  plats and whether the parties agreed upon the actual boundaries for the property.Â  
  Ficiâ€™s counsel specifically addressed whether the contract would be enforceable 
  under the statute of frauds standing alone and also after considering all the 
  additional testimony, plats, and other exhibits in the case.Â  Additionally, 
  Ficiâ€™s counsel asked one of the Koonsâ€™ witnesses whether the Statute of Frauds 
  should be specifically pled.Â  As a result of this questioning, the motion to 
  amend was made.Â  
We find the parties impliedly tried the Statute of Frauds issue.Â  In addition, 
  Fici has failed to demonstrate how she was prejudiced by the amendment as she 
  raised the issue herself with several witnesses.Â  Accordingly, we conclude the 
  master properly allowed the Koons to amend their Answer to conform to the evidence 
  presented at trial.
II.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Specific 
  Performance and Statute of Frauds
Fici asserts the master erred in finding the contract failed to satisfy the 
  Statute of Frauds.Â  She maintains writings exist which can charge the Koons 
  with the boundary lines determining the property to be sold.Â  Finally, she contends 
  the master erred in failing to order specific performance of the contract.Â  
  We disagree and find the contract fails to satisfy the Statute of Frauds.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  The Statute of Frauds requires that:

  
No action shall be brought whereby: . . . (4) To charge any person upon any 
  contract or sale of lands, tenements or hereditaments or any interest in or 
  concerning them . . . [u]nless the agreement upon which such action shall be 
  brought or some memorandum or note thereof shall be in writing and signed by 
  the party to be charged therewith or some person thereunto by him lawfully authorized.
  

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 32-3-10 (1976).

The South Carolina Supreme Court has held:
  
One of the essential 
  terms of a contract of sale of land is the identification of the land.Â  A decree 
  for specific performance operates as a deed.Â  Hence, the land must be described 
  so as to indicate with reasonable certainty what is to be conveyed.Â  Parol evidence 
  cannot be relied upon to supplement a vague and uncertain description.Â  
  

Cash v. Maddox, 265 S.C. 480, 484, 220 S.E.2d 121, 122 (1975) (internal 
  citations omitted).
The court further explained:Â  â€œFor a contract to meet the requirements of the 
  Statute of Frauds, . . . , every essential element of the sale must be expressed 
  therein. . . . Parol evidence may be used to explain terms appearing in the 
  description, but the description itself must clearly identify the particular 
  parcel of land.â€Â  Id.Â  In Cash, the only evidence of the property 
  being sold was that it consisted of 15 acres.Â  The parties never agreed which 
  15 acres were to be sold.Â  Id. at 484, 220 S.E.2d at 122.
Cash is indistinguishable from the instant case.Â  As there was no way 
  to determine from the writings in Cash which 15 acres the parties intended 
  to convey, there is no way to determine from the contract in the instant case 
  which 30 acres the parties intended to convey.
In order to satisfy the 
  Statute of Frauds, Fici would have to show some other writings, which when read 
  together with the sales contract provide a complete description of the property 
  to be conveyed and all other essential terms of the contract.Â  

It is well settled that 
  the form of writing required by the statute is not material.Â  The contract may 
  be evidenced by one writing or more. . . . Whatever form the agreement may assume, 
  if the writing or writings, viewed as a whole, constitute, in essence or substance 
  upon their face, a note or memorandum in writing, subscribed by the party sought 
  to be charged, showing who the contracting parties are, the subject matter of 
  the sale, and the consideration, the statute is satisfied.

Speed v. Speed, 
  213 S.C. 401, 408, 49 S.E.2d 588, 593 (1948).
The Koons and/or their agent have signed only two writings.Â  The first is the 
  plat all three parties signed with the hand drawn boundaries.Â  However, all 
  parties agreed the plat was not indicative of the final boundaries, and all 
  actions subsequent to the signing of the plat indicated the parties still needed 
  to establish the proper boundaries.Â  In addition, the plat signed specifically 
  stated on its face:Â  â€œSurvey to be performed week of March 12 by CTH Surveyors.â€Â  

The only other writing, which was â€œsigned,â€ was the request for admission answered 
  by the Koons that was signed and filed by their attorney.Â  The requests included 
  two pertinent questions:

16.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  That the Defendants were in agreement for the New Plat to be prepared 
  showing and delineating a fifty foot wide driveway easement extending from Miles 
  Bowman Road to the Property at the southwestern most corner of Tract 2 as shown 
  on the New Plat.
17.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  That the Defendants were in agreement for the New Plat to be prepared 
  with the property lines for the three tracts as shown on the New Plat.Â  (Plaintiffâ€™s 
  Exhibits 48 & 49). Â 

The Koons denied the first question and admitted the second.Â  The second question 
  only admits the parties planned for a plat to be prepared.Â  This is the same 
  as what the contract called for originally.Â  Fici fails to indicate a plat upon 
  which all three parties have agreed to the final boundaries.Â  Until the parties 
  have defined those boundaries with reasonable certainty, the Statute of Frauds 
  has not been satisfied.Â  Accordingly, we find the master properly determined 
  the Statute of Frauds bars enforcement of the contract for sale. 
  [2] 
III.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Attorneyâ€™s 
  Fees
The Koons assert the master erred in failing to award attorneyâ€™s fees under 
  the contract or in the alternative as a result of Ficiâ€™s improper withdrawal 
  of the funds from the Wachovia account.Â  We disagree and find the master properly 
  refused to order attorneyâ€™s fees.

A. Â Â Â Â  Under the Contract

Â â€œThe general rule is 
  that attorneyâ€™s fees are not recoverable unless authorized by contract or statute.â€Â  
  Baron Data Sys., Inc. v. Loter, 297 S.C. 382, 383-84, 377 S.E.2d 296, 
  297 (1989).Â  â€œWhen there is a contract, the award of attorneyâ€™s fees is left 
  to the discretion of the trial judge and will not be disturbed unless an abuse 
  of discretion is shown.â€Â  Id.
The contract in the instant case provided for attorneyâ€™s fees to be awarded:Â  
  â€œIn any action to enforce the provisions of this Contract, the prevailing party 
  and Broker(s) shall be entitled to the award of their costs, including reasonable 
  attorneyâ€™s fees.â€Â  This provision, however, appears in a section of the contract 
  labeled Default.Â  The section details the rights of each party in the event 
  the other defaults on certain provisions of the contract.Â  
â€œThe purpose of all rules of contract construction is to ascertain the intention 
  of the parties to the contract.Â  Where the agreement in question is a written 
  contract, the partiesâ€™ intention must be gathered from the contents of the entire 
  agreement and not from any particular clause thereof.â€Â  Thomas-McCain, Inc. 
  v. Siter, 268 S.C. 193, 197, 232 S.E.2d 728, 729 (1977).
We find the language of the contract is clear that the parties intended the 
  attorney fee provision to be read as part of the section on default and not 
  as an isolated provision.Â  Also, the provision should not stand alone once we 
  have made the determination that the contract is unenforceable under the Statute 
  of Frauds.Â  Because it was impossible for either party to default under the 
  unenforceable contract, we find neither party would be entitled to attorneyâ€™s 
  fees under this provision. 

B.Â Â Â Â Â  As a Result of Ficiâ€™s Withdrawal of Money

The account was established as part of the circuit courtâ€™s order granting Ficiâ€™s 
  request for a temporary injunction.Â  The court, citing Rule 65(c), SCRCP and 
  section 15-1-250 of the South Carolina Code, required the deposit of funds into 
  the Wachovia account.Â  The court, quoting the rule, found the deposit was needed 
  â€œfor the payment of such costs and damages as may be incurred or suffered by 
  any party who is found to have been wrongfully enjoined or restrained.â€Â  The 
  court ordered:Â  â€œthe Plaintiff will agree not to make any disbursement from 
  the account during the pendency of this action.â€Â  
The Koons filed a Contempt Complaint and a Rule to Show Cause seeking to determine 
  why Fici should not be held in contempt for withdrawing the money from the Wachovia 
  account.Â  With the partiesâ€™ consent, the master addressed the contempt issue 
  as an additional motion instead of issuing the Rule to Show Cause and the matter 
  was argued along with the partiesâ€™ other post-trial motions.Â  The court took 
  testimony on the issue including testimony from Fici.Â  Fici explained that she 
  withdrew the money upon advice from her attorney that it was appropriate to 
  do so.Â  
Contempt results from the willful disobedience of a court order, and before 
  a court may find a person in contempt, the record must clearly and specifically 
  reflect the contemptuous conduct.Â  Henderson v. Henderson, 298 S.C. 190, 
  197, 379 S.E.2d 125, 129 (1989).Â  A willful act is one which is â€œdone voluntarily 
  and intentionally with the specific intent to do something the law forbids, 
  or with the specific intent to fail to do something the law requires to be done; 
  that is to say, with bad purpose either to disobey or disregard the law.â€Â  Spartanburg 
  County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Padgett, 296 S.C. 79, 82-83, 370 S.E.2d 872, 
  874 (1988).Â  â€œIn a proceeding for contempt for violation of a court order, the 
  moving party must show the existence of the order, and the facts establishing 
  the respondentâ€™s noncompliance.â€Â  Brasington v. Shannon, 288 S.C. 183, 
  184, 341 S.E.2d 130, 131 (1986).Â  
Once the moving party has made out a prima facie case, the burden then shifts 
  to the respondent to establish his or her defense and inability to comply with 
  the order.Â  Henderson, 298 S.C. at 197, 379 S.E.2d at 129.Â  A determination 
  of contempt is within the sound discretion of the trial judge, but his decision 
  will be reversed when the finding is without evidentiary support or there is 
  an abuse of discretion.Â  Wilson v. Walker, 340 S.C. 531, 538, 532 S.E.2d 
  19, 22 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  Even if a party is found in contempt, the party need 
  not be sanctioned for the conduct.Â  See Sutton v. Sutton, 291 
  S.C. 401, 409, 353 S.E.2d 884, 888-89 (Ct. App. 1987).
Thus, having determined Fici did not willfully violate the court order, the 
  master found no reason to hold her in contempt.Â  We agree.Â  Based on our reading 
  of the record, we find the master did not abuse his discretion in finding the 
  Koons were not entitled to attorneyâ€™s fees as a result of Ficiâ€™s withdrawal 
  of the money.  [3] 
CONCLUSION
We find the master properly allowed the Koons to amend their Answer to conform 
  to the evidence already admitted and argued by the parties.Â  We hold there are 
  no writings in evidence, which describe with reasonable certainty the boundaries 
  intended by the parties.Â  Therefore, we conclude the contract and all subsequent 
  writings fail to satisfy the Statute of Frauds.Â  Finally, we find neither party 
  is entitled to attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Accordingly, the masterâ€™s decision is
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, ANDERSON, and WILLIAMS JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1]  The actions against Hipp and the brokerage are not at issue in this 
    appeal.

 
   
    [2]  In determining the contract is unenforceable, we need not determine 
    the validity of the restrictive covenants or whether the Koons breached the 
    contract by filing the restrictive covenants.

 
   
    [3]  Fici also requests attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  As we have concluded the master 
    properly denied her claim for specific performance, Fici is not entitled to 
    attorneyâ€™s fees.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Carroll Rogers and Windy Hill Water Park, Inc., Appellants,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Jill R. Griffith and Bellamy, Rutenberg, Copeland, Epps, Gravely & Bowers, P.A., Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
Â J. Michael Baxley, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-555
\Submitted September 15, 2004 â€“ Filed November 4, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Bradley A. Coxe, of Wrightsville Beach, for Appellant.
        Andrew E. Haselden and R. Davis Howser, both of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.: In this action for professional malpractice, Appellants Windy Hill Water Park and the companyâ€™s part owner, Carroll Rogers, (collectively, â€œWindy Hillâ€) challenge the trial courtâ€™s denial of a motion for a new trial.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
In December of 1996, Windy Hill contacted the Bellamy Law Firm to assist in the preparation of a lease agreement to cover leasing the companyâ€™s aquatic amusement park in North Myrtle Beach, South Carolina.Â  Respondent Jill Griffith, an attorney with the Bellamy Law Firm, prepared the requested lease documents.Â  After the original lessee withdrew from negotiations, Windy Hill solicited Richard C. Huggins, William Vaught, Jr., and William Vaught, III as new prospective lessees (collectively, â€œthe Lesseesâ€).Â  At no point did Griffith assist in Windy Hillâ€™s negotiations with the Lessees.Â  Instead, Griffithâ€™s services were limited to drafting the agreement revisions requested by Windy Hill.Â  
On January 27, 1997, Windy Hill asked Griffith to add a paragraph to the lease agreement requiring the Lessees to grant Windy Hill a third mortgage on the residence of William Vaught, Jr. and a second mortgage on property adjoining the residence.Â  Griffith added the requested language to the lease agreement.Â  Based on representations made by Lessees, it was Windy Hillâ€™s understanding that the $350,000.00 mortgage described by the new paragraph would be subordinate in priority to only $62,000.00 in other mortgages.Â  

The following day, Windy Hill met the Lessees and Griffith at the Bellamy Law Firm for the scheduled execution of the lease.Â  When it became clear that the mortgages required by the lease agreementâ€™s new paragraph had not been prepared, Griffith agreed to prepare the mortgages.Â  According to Griffith, she warned Windy Hill that no title search had been performed and that one could not be performed immediately.Â  Windy Hill chose to go forward without the title search.Â  The lease and mortgage documents were then executed, and Griffith stamped â€œDOCUMENTS PREPARED WITHOUT BENEFIT OF TITLE SEARCHâ€ on the face of the mortgage.Â  
The Lessees began operating a water park on Memorial Day, 1997, but made only three payments to Windy Hill before defaulting on the lease agreement.Â  With the Lessees in default, Windy Hill terminated the lease and took possession and control of the Lesseesâ€™ water park.Â  When Windy Hill began collection and foreclosure proceedings against the Lessees, a title search revealed the Vaughtsâ€™ property was actually encumbered by $131,550.50 in mortgages with priority over Windy Hill rather than $62,000.00 as had been previously understood.Â  
Windy Hill brought this action alleging professional negligence on the part of Griffith and the Bellamy Law Firm in the preparation of the mortgage without a title search.Â  Griffith and the Bellamy Law Firm answered and asserted a general denial to the material allegations contained in the complaint.Â  Prior to trial, the trial court bifurcated the issues of damages and liability.Â  After three days of testimony, jury deliberations began on a Friday, at approximately 4:00 p.m. and continued until approximately 8:15 p.m.Â  The jury resumed deliberations the following Monday at 10:00 a.m. before delivering a verdict in favor of Griffith at approximately 11:45 a.m.Â  
In a hearing held after the trial, Windy Hill moved for a new trial on two independent grounds.Â  First, Windy Hill urged the court to invoke the thirteenth juror doctrine because the juryâ€™s verdict was against the greater weight of the evidence.Â  Second, Windy Hill argued the trial had been tainted by juror misconduct.Â  In support of this argument, Windy Hill offered the affidavit of Catherine Anthony, a juror from the trial, stating she noticed some of the jurors discussing the case Friday evening after ending deliberations for the weekend.Â  The trial court denied Windy Hillâ€™s motion.Â  This appeal followed.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Thirteenth Juror Doctrine
Windy Hill contends the trial court erred by denying its post-trial motion for a new trial based on the thirteenth juror doctrine.Â  We disagree.
South Carolinaâ€™s thirteenth juror doctrine grants a trial court judge significant discretionary authority to grant a new trial when the judge concludes the evidence does not justify the verdict.Â  Norton v. Norfolk S. Ry. Co., 350 S.C. 473, 478, 567 S.E.2d 851, 854 (2002).Â  As a matter addressed to the trial judgeâ€™s discretion, we will uphold a judgeâ€™s order granting or denying a new trial unless the order is â€œwholly unsupported by the evidence, or [the] conclusion reached was controlled by [an] error of law.â€Â  Folkens v. Hunt, 300 S.C. 251, 254-55, 387 S.E.2d 265, 267 (1990).Â  Here, because substantial testimony and numerous exhibits corroborated Griffithâ€™s defenseâ€”that she had been retained only for purposes of drafting a lease agreement and had warned Windy Hill about the lack of a title searchâ€”we cannot conclude the trial courtâ€™s decision not to disturb the jury verdict is wholly unsupported by the evidence.Â Â Â  Accordingly, we find no error in the trial courtâ€™s refusal to grant a new trial based on the thirteenth juror doctrine.
Juror Misconduct
Windy Hill next contends the trial court erred in not granting a new trial based on juror misconduct.Â  We disagree.

Rule 606(b), SCRE, provides as follows: 

  Inquiry Into Validity of Verdict or Indictment. Upon an inquiry into the validity of a verdict or indictment, a juror may not testify as to any matter or statement occurring during the course of the juryâ€™s deliberations or to the effect of anything upon that or any other jurorâ€™s mind or emotions as influencing the juror to assent to or dissent from the verdict or indictment or concerning the jurorâ€™s mental processes in connection therewith, except that a juror may testify on the question whether extraneous prejudicial information was improperly brought to the juryâ€™s attention or whether any outside influence was improperly brought to bear upon any juror. Nor may a jurorâ€™s affidavit or evidence of any statement by the juror concerning a matter about which the juror would be precluded from testifying be received for these purposes.

Rather than basing its new trial motion on any extraneous prejudicial information improperly brought to the juryâ€™s attention, Windy Hillâ€™s motion is based solely upon allegations of internal misconduct.Â  
Although the South Carolina Supreme Court has indicated juror testimony may be admissible about internal conduct to ensure fundamental fairness, State v. Aldret, 333 S.C. 307, 311, 509 S.E.2d 811, 812 (1999), we find the exception inapplicable to the present case.Â  At the outset, we note that Aldretâ€™s limited exception to the rule prohibiting testimony about internal conduct has never been applied outside criminal cases.Â  See State v. Franklin, 341 S.C. 555, 534 S.E.2d 716 (Ct. App. 2000); State v. Hunter, 320 S.C. 85, 463 S.E.2d 314 (1995).Â Â  Moreover, nothing in the present case suggests the fundamental fairness of the trial process was placed in jeopardy.Â  According to Windy Hill, the alleged misconduct warranting a new trial was the statement by one juror that she â€œobserved jurors continuing to discuss the case Friday night after the deliberations had ceased in small groups.â€Â  This is not a case of premature deliberations; rather, the judge had already charged the jury with the law.Â  While a jury should refrain from discussing a case outside the confines of the jury room, the mere existence of such a discussion does not imply impropriety warranting judicial inquiry.Â  Therefore, the trial court committed no error in declining to grant a new trial.
AFFIRMED.Â  
HUFF and CURETON, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Henry Mims, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Arthur Myers, Sarah Lee Myers, Jones and Robert Myers, Rubena Myers, Rosa Bell Martin, Bryant Glover, Jr., Leroy Jones, Rosetta Carol and Deborah Mitchell, Defendants,
        Of Whom Arthur Myers and Bryant Glover, Jr., are, Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Aiken County
James L. Verenes, Special Referee

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2004-UP-556
Submitted October 1, 2004 â€“ Filed November 4, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Franklin D. Beattie, Jr., and Marvin B. Poston, both of Aiken, for Appellants.
        M. Anderson Griffith, of Aiken, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Arthur Myers and Bryant Glover (collectively Appellants) appeal a special refereeâ€™s decision upholding the tax sale of their property.Â  They argue that selling the entire property to satisfy unpaid taxes was excessive, and therefore invalid as a matter of law.Â  Appellants contend the property should have been divided and only a portion of the property sold.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
In 1965, James Myers devised a forty-acre tract of land to his wife, Annie Mae Myers, and his five children.Â  In 1976, Annie Myers died intestate and her undivided interest passed through inheritance to the five children. The property was partitioned among the children into eight separate five-acre tracts.
In 2000, the property taxes were not paid on two of the tracts.Â  Appellants stipulated that they received all default tax notices pursuant to the statutory requirements, but took no action on the notices.Â  The tracts were seized for nonpayment of taxes for 1999 and 2000 in the amount of $538.92 each.Â  
Following the tractsâ€™ seizure, Aiken County auctioned off the land for repayment of the delinquent taxes.Â  Though properly notified, Appellants did not attend the sale.Â  At the sale, the Aiken County Forfeited Land Commission successfully bid on the property. 
Following the sale, the county tax assessor began the process of setting off the divided portions of the tracts.Â  In response to the tax assessorâ€™s request for a description of the divided property, the Aiken County Planning and Development Board informed the tax assessor that dividing the tracts would violate Aiken County Subdivision regulations in regard to recorded easements.Â  The Commission, therefore, added the notation â€œSELL ALLâ€ to the both properties.Â Â Â  
In November 2000, Henry Mims purchased the two parcels of land in their entirety from Aiken County for $548.65 each.Â  Appellants took no action during the subsequent redemption period and, in March 2002, Mims received a deed for each tract.Â  The following July, Mims brought an action against the Appellants to quiet title to the land purchased at the tax sale.Â  Appellants argued the tax sale was invalid because selling the entire property to satisfy $1,223 of unpaid taxes was excessive and invalid as a matter of law.Â  The Special Referee found that the tax sale was proper.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEWÂ  
An action to set aside a tax deed is in equity.Â  S.C. Fed. Sav. Bank v. Atl. Land Title Co., Inc., 314 S.C. 292, 294, 442 S.E.2d 630, 631 (Ct. App. 1994).Â  Therefore, this court may take its own view of the preponderance of evidence.Â  Townes Assocs., Ltd. v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 86, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775-76 (1976). 
LAW/ANALYSIS 
I. Divisibility Study
At the time of the tax sale, the statute containing the procedure for conducting a tax sale provided in part as follows:

  When the real property is divisible, the tax assessor, county treasurer, and county auditor shall ascertain that portion of the property that is sufficient to realize a sum upon sale sufficient to satisfy the payment of the taxes . . . In such cases, the officer shall partition the property and furnish a legal description of it. 

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-51-40(d) (2000) (emphasis added).Â  This statutory language was amended in 2000 and the word â€œshallâ€ was replaced by â€œmay.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-51-40(d) (Supp. 2003).Â  Thus, the amended statute made it permissive rather than mandatory for the tax assessor, county treasurer, or auditor to divide the property. 
Appellants argue the applicable statute was the pre-amendment version in place at the time of the levy, thus the county was required to divide the property if feasible.Â  Since the referee found division was not required, it is their contention he erred by applying the current version, and not the pre-amendment version, of section 12-51-40(d).Â  We disagree.
Appellants overlook that the referee did, in fact, apply the pre-amendment version of the statute. The South Carolina Supreme Court interpreted the prior version of the tax sale statute in Folk v. Thomas, 344 S.C. 77, 543 S.E.2d 556 (2001), and held, notwithstanding the pre-amendment mandatory language, that the defaulting taxpayer, and not the county, bore the initial burden of requesting a determination of possible property division.Â  The later amendments to the statute were merely a codification of this holding.Â  
In the case at bar, Appellants never raised the issue of divisibility nor did they request a divisibility study.Â  Accordingly, we hold that the mandatory language in section 12-51-40(d) did not place a pre-sale burden on the county to determine whether the property was divisible.Â  The tax sale, therefore, was statutorily proper.[1] 
II. Excessiveness of the Sale
Appellants also argue selling the entire tracts, valued at $20,274 each, for taxes due in the amount of $611.95 per tract was excessive and invalid as a matter of law.Â  Again, we disagree.
In a tax sale of real property, â€œ[t]here are no fixed guidelines as to what constitutes excessive levy.â€Â  S.C. Fed. Sav. Bank v. Atl. Land Title Co., Inc., 314 S.C. 292, 297, 442 S.E.2d 630, 633 (Ct. App. 1994).Â  â€œA tax sale does not necessarily exact an excessive levy . . . because it brings an inadequate price.â€Â  Id.Â  Inadequate consideration alone is not a sufficient reason to set aside a tax sale.Â  It must be coupled with other inequitable circumstances, such as fraud, mistake, misapprehension, surprise, or other such factors. Patterson v. Goldsmith, 292 S.C. 619, 628, 358 S.E.2d 163, 168 (Ct. App. 1987).
Appellants argue equitable relief should be granted based on mutual mistake and unjust enrichment.Â  The facts of the case, however, do not support these allegations.Â  Internal county documents showing that the county was considering selling only a portion of the properties are simply not sufficient to show a mistake between the parties.Â  On the contrary, by the time of the sale to Mims, the county tax office was aware that dividing the properties was not a viable option.
We likewise find no merit in Appellantsâ€™ claim of unjust enrichment.Â  Appellants admit they failed to take any action on the default notices and made no request for a divisibility study.Â  Moreover, Appellants have not challenged the special refereeâ€™s finding that the properties could not have been divided, even if a divisibility study was done.Â  Appellants did not raise the issues of excessiveness or divisibility until after Mims received his deed.Â  Despite adequate notice, they did not participate in the sale, nor did they take any action during the statutory redemption period.Â  Therefore, we conclude Appellants slept on their rights and cannot now demand their rights in equity.Â  See Folk, 344 S.C. at 83, 543 S.E.2d at 559 (2001) (â€œIt was . . . the defaulting taxpayer . . . who slept on his rights, did not pay his taxes for two years, failed to respond to any of the certified notices sent by the tax collector, and failed to show up at the tax sale.â€).
III. Improper Advertising of Tax Sale
Finally, Appellants argue the tax sale advertising violated the proper statutory guidelines.Â  We find this argument to be without merit.
Regarding advertisements for public sale, the tax sale statute requires that: 1) the property be advertised for sale at public auction; 2) the advertisement should be in a newspaper of general circulation; 3) the advertisement must be entitled â€œDelinquent Tax Sale,â€ and; 4) the advertisement must include the taxpayerâ€™s name and a description of property.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-51-40(d) (Supp. 1999).Â  The statute also notes that reference to a parcel number is a sufficient description of property. Id. 
Appellants rely on Hawkins v. Bruno Yacht Sales, Inc., 342 S.C. 352, 536 S.E.2d 698 (Ct. App. 2000), for the proposition that the statutory requirements for notice must be strictly construed against the County, and a sale must be set aside if the description of the property is deficient in any respect.Â  We note, however, that Hawkins was modified on appeal by the South Carolina Supreme Court on the issue of advertisement, and the property description in that case was held to be sufficient.Â  Hawkins v. Bruno Yacht Sales, Inc., 353 S.C. 31, 40-41, 577 S.E.2d 202, 207-08 (2003).
In Hawkins, the description of the property to be soldâ€”a fifty-two foot sailboatâ€”did not describe the property as a sailboat, but only included the defaulting taxpayerâ€™s name and a delinquent tax number.Â  Id. at 40, 577 S.E.2d at 207.Â  Nevertheless, our supreme court found the advertisement sufficient due to the fact that it met the requirements of section 12-51-40(d) of the South Carolina Code.Â  Id. at 41, 577 S.E.2d at 208.Â  Hawkins is analogous to the case at hand, because in this case, the county used a tax parcel number to describe the land being sold.Â  Accordingly, we find the county provided a sufficient description of the property.
Appellants also argue the sale was improperly advertised because a printout from the Aiken County Tax Offices contained handwritten notations next to each property showing that the sale of â€œ1.0 acreâ€ would cover the taxes due.Â  However, Appellants have not presented any evidence that this document, entitled â€œparcels of land to be carved up for tax sale,â€ was ever used to advertise the property for sale.Â  The special referee found the acreage reference was present only in some inter-office memos.Â  The newspaper advertisement relied on the propertiesâ€™ tax parcel number, which was an adequate description of both properties.Â  As a result, we find the advertisement was proper.
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, the special refereeâ€™s decision is
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, ANDERSON, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.


[1] Appellants also argue the tax sale violated sections 12-51-70, -130, and -150 of the South Carolina Code (2000 & Supp. 2003).Â  Because these issues were raised for the first time in Appellantsâ€™ Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion, and not during the trial before the special referee, they are not preserved for our review.Â  See Patterson v. Reid, 318 S.C. 183, 185, 456 S.E. 2d 436, 437 (Ct. App. 1995) (â€œA party cannot for the first time raise an issue by way of a rule 59(e) motion which could have been raised at trial.â€).Â  We note, however, that even if these issues were preserved, none of the statutory provisions would require the sale to be voided because the county did not follow the statutory scheme.

FACTS
Tucker was indicted by a Greenville

THE COURT:Â  Now, thatâ€”and I understand you want to tender

  plead?
DEFENDANT TUCKER:Â  Guilty.
THE COURT:Â  Now, has anybody forced you, coerced you, threatened 
  you, or promised you anything in any way to get you to enter a plea of guilty?
DEFENDANT TUCKER:Â  No, sir. 
THE COURT:Â  And are you doing it freely 
  and voluntarily?
DEFENDANT TUCKER: Yes, sir.
THE COURT:Â  Okay.Â  Do you understand that you have an absolute 
  right to a trial by jury where you would be presumed innocent unless and until 
  the Government could prove you guilty beyond any reasonable doubt of each and 
  every element of the offense that youâ€™re charged with?Â  
DEFENDANT TUCKER:Â  Yes, sir.
THE COURT:Â  You have a right to confront and cross-examine

DEFENDANT TUCKER:Â  Yes, sir.

The State recited the facts of the case,

  me to leave, chased me out to the car, and even going to the extent of getting

  get the keys back still.Â  All this, you know, to go home.Â

  The first time was in the elbow, and then once around my forearm, Iâ€™ve got a 
  scar there still, and once on the side of the head.Â Â  
And, at that point, thatâ€™s when I justâ€”actually, when I hit, 
  I had my eyes shut and everything.Â  I just swung to get her off of me.Â  I donâ€™t 
  recall her being unconscious at all.Â  I looked at her.Â  I said, â€œAre you okay?â€Â

I took her to the bathroom and got a towel.Â  There was no

The court next addressed Tuckerâ€™s claim 
  that he was not living with Rocket when the incident took place.Â  

THE COURT:Â  This is a guilty plea.
DEFENDANT TUCKER:Â  Right.
THE COURT:Â  And one of theâ€”and, as I told you, the State has 
  got to prove beyond a reasonable doubt each of the elements of the offense that 
  youâ€™re charged with.
DEFENDANT TUCKER:Â  Right.
THE COURT:Â  And that is an essential element of the charge.Â  
  So if it is your position that you are not a household member with the alleged 
  victim in this case, then Iâ€™m not going to accept your guilty plea.
If you donâ€™t feel that you were living there, then this is 
  not criminal domestic violence.
DEFENDANT TUCKER:Â  Well, all Iâ€™mâ€”the whole story is she came 
  down fromâ€”she lived in North Carolina.Â  She came down.Â  She stayed at our house, 
  my parents.Â  I live at home still now.Â  She stayed with my parents until she 
  could find a place to live. 
My dad actually helped her find that house.Â  It was a friend 
  of his that rented it.Â  And I had even told her, I was like, you know, I said, 
  Iâ€™ll help you some with money, whatever.Â  And I had stayed there some, but not 
  to the point of living there.Â  I lived at home.Â  Workâ€”if I had to go to work 
  the next day, I would go home.
MR. PASCHAL:Â  But you had clothes and 
  â€“ 
DEFENDANT TUCKER:Â  I had a few clothes there.Â  I would change 
  sometimes when I went there after work.Â  But to say I lived there is not fully 
  true.Â  
 . . . . 
THE COURT:Â  But you have described what might be construed 
  as a self-defense argument.Â  And I want to tell you that if you enter this guilty 
  plea and I accept it, that whatever defenses you may have, you waive and give 
  up the right to present those.Â  That doesnâ€™t say you canâ€™t present that information 
  as mitigation.
But just so you understand that if you have any question 
  as to theâ€”whether or not you have a defense in this matter, if you plead and 
  I accept it, you give up your right to use that defense.Â  
Do you understand that?
DEFENDANT TUCKER:Â  Right.Â  

Subsequently, Tucker admitted that at times he 
  stayed with his parents while at other times he stayed with Rocket.Â  After â€œfinding 
  that he was, in fact, a household member,â€ the court addressed the possibility 
  of a self-defense claim:

THE COURT:Â  How about the self-defense, 
  Mr. Paschal?
MR. PASCHAL:Â  Your Honor, I think you asked him about that 
  and I think he realizes that, but heâ€™s not saying that heâ€™sâ€”
THE COURT:Â  All right.Â  Well, Iâ€™ll accept the plea as being 
  knowingly, intelligently, and voluntarily made with the advice of a very competent 
  attorney with whom he states heâ€™s well satisfied, and there is a factual basis 
  for the plea. 

On appeal, Tucker argues (1) the trial 
  court should not have entered a guilty plea because Tucker maintained that he 
  acted in self-defense, and (2) the court failed to conduct a sufficient inquiry 
  under. North Carolina v. Alford, 400 U.S. 25 (1970).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Self-Defense
First, Tucker argues the trial court erred 
  in accepting his plea because he maintained that he acted in self-defense.Â  
  We disagree.Â  
Initially, this allegation is not properly before 
  this Court on direct appeal since the alleged error was not raised below.Â  In 
  the Interest of Antonio H., 324 S.C. 120, 477 S.E.2d 713 (1996) (proper 
  avenue in which to challenge guilty plea which is not objected to at time of 
  its entry is through post-conviction relief); State v. Williams, 303 
  S.C. 410, 401 S.E.2d 168 (1991) (defendant must object at first opportunity 
  to preserve issue for appellate review; alleged error must be raised to and 
  ruled on by trial judge); State v. McKinney, 278 S.C. 107, 292 S.E.2d 
  598 (1982) (absent timely objection at plea proceeding, unknowing and involuntary 
  nature of guilty plea can be attacked only through more appropriate channel 
  of post-conviction relief).
Moreover, as to the merits, we disagree with Tuckerâ€™s 
  claim that he did not admit culpability.Â  The trial court thoroughly informed 
  Tucker of his various constitutional rights.Â  Tucker indicated he understood 
  his rights and that he wanted to give up those rights and plead guilty:

THE COURT:Â  Do you want to waive and give up those rights 
  and plead guilty?
DEFENDANT TUCKER:Â  Yes, sir. 
THE COURT:Â  Are you guilty?
DEFENDANT TUCKER:Â  Uh, yes, sir.Â  

If Tucker felt that he was not guilty, or that he 
  wanted to assert a defense, he should not have admitted guilt, and he should 
  not have entered a guilty plea.Â  
Further, the trial court specifically stated that 
  â€œyou have described what might be construed as a self-defense argumentâ€ and 
  informed Tucker that by pleading guilty, he waived any defenses that he may 
  have had.Â  Again, Tucker indicated that he understood.Â  Consequently, we are 
  convinced that Tucker entered a plea of guilty and waived any potential claim 
  of self-defense.Â  See State v. Thomason, 341 S.C. 524, 534 S.E.2d 
  708 (Ct. App. 2000) (finding a guilty plea admits all elements of the offense 
  charged, leaves open for review only the sufficiency of the indictment, and 
  waives all other defenses).
II.Â  North Carolina v. Alford
Next, Tucker argues that due to the absence 
  of an admission of culpability, the court failed to conduct sufficient inquiry 
  under North Carolina v. Alford, 400 U.S. 25 (1970).Â  We disagree.
As with the self-defense argument, this argument 
  is not properly before this Court because Tucker did not raise an objection 
  at the plea hearing.Â  In the Interest of Antonio H., 324 S.C. 120, 477 
  S.E.2d 713 (1996) (proper avenue in which to challenge guilty plea which is 
  not objected to at time of its entry is through post-conviction relief); State 
  v. Williams, 303 S.C. 410, 401 S.E.2d 168 (1991) (defendant must object 
  at first opportunity to preserve issue for appellate review; alleged error must 
  be raised to and ruled on by trial judge); State v. McKinney, 278 S.C. 
  107, 292 S.E.2d 598 (1982) (absent timely objection at plea proceeding, unknowing 
  and involuntary nature of guilty plea can be attacked only through more appropriate 
  channel of post-conviction relief).
Nonetheless, we find this argument without merit.Â  
  Tucker did admit culpability, and he entered a guilty plea.Â  Therefore, the 
  court had no reason to alternatively accept the plea under Alford; that 
  case has no application here.Â  
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, the decision of the circuit 
  court is 
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, STILWELL, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

  with the requirements set forth in Boykin v. Alabama, 395 U.S. 238 (1969).Â  
  Pursuant to Anders v. California, 386 U.S. 738 (1967), Vaughnâ€™s counsel 
  attached a petition to be relieved stating that he has reviewed the record and 
  found the appeal to be without merit.Â  Vaughn has also filed a pro se 
  response in which he argues the pleas were not voluntarily made because he was 
  not informed of their sentencing consequences.Â Â  
After a thorough review of the record pursuant 
  to Anders and State v. Williams, 305 S.C. 116, 406 S.E.2d 357 
  (1991), we dismiss the appeal and grant counselâ€™s petition to be relieved.Â  

APPEAL DISMISSED. 
  [1] 
 HEARN C.J., GOOLSBY, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.
