THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE 
  CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Louise Wellington, as GAL for Johnny Lee Sanders,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Roberta Floyd, individually, and as Administrator of Manor House of Olanta 
        and Manor House of Olanta,        Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Florence County
B. Hicks Harwell, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-575
Submitted October 1, 2004 â€“ Filed November 
  16, 2004 


REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Ralph J. Wilson, of Conway, for Appellant.
Thomas H. Milligan, of Mt. Pleasant, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Louise Wellington, Guardian 
  Ad Litem for Johnny Lee Sanders, appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order granting 
  Respondentâ€™s motion for summary judgment on Sandersâ€™ action for breach of duty 
  of care.Â  We reverse and remand. [1] 
 FACTS
  In 1987, an injury to Sandersâ€™ head rendered 
    him incapable of living independently.Â  Sanders also suffered from seizures 
    as a result of the injury and had to take several medications daily to control 
    the seizures.Â  In 2000, Sanders became a resident of Manor House of Olanta, 
    a residential care facility in Olanta, South Carolina.Â  In the contract between 
    the parties, Manor House agreed to provide Sanders with certain services, 
    mainly room and board, laundry, and the supervision and administration of 
    medications, although upon admission into the facility Sanderâ€™s doctor 
    declared him â€œcapable of self administration of medications.â€Â  The contract 
    also provided that Sanders could â€œcome and go as he please[d].â€Â  
  Sanders left the premises of the residential 
    care facility on April 11, 2001.Â  Upon leaving the facility, he was arrested 
    for trespassing and spent more than two weeks in the Effingham Jail in the 
    custody of the Florence County Sheriffâ€™s Department, until he was released 
    to the care of his sister.Â  Manor House did not know of Sandersâ€™ whereabouts 
    during the two-week period and did not attempt to find Sanders or notify his 
    family members of his absence.Â  Three days after being released to his sisterâ€™s 
    care, Sanders suffered seizures.
  As an assisted living facility, Manor House of Olanta 
    is licensed under the South Carolina Department of Health and Environmental 
    Controlâ€™s Regulations.Â  25A S.C.Code Ann.Regs. 61-84 (Supp. 2000).Â  The regulations 
    require a facility to immediately report residents who have left the facility 
    under circumstances that raise concern about the residentâ€™s safety to any 
    agency providing services to the resident, next of kin, and local law enforcement.Â  
    Id. at Â§ 404 (c).Â Â Â  
  Sanders brought an action against Roberta Floyd, 
    individually and as Administrator of Manor House of Olanta, and Manor House 
    of Olanta (Respondents) for breach of duty of care, arguing that the regulations 
    create a duty of care for a negligence per se action.Â  Respondents 
    filed a Motion for Summary Judgment with a Memorandum in support of the Motion, 
    arguing that the licensing regulations do not provide Sanders with a cause 
    of action, and the obligations of the parties are governed merely by the contract 
    between them.Â  
  The Clerk of Court notified the parties that 
    a hearing would be held on August 29, 2002.Â  Respondentâ€™s counsel also notified 
    Sandersâ€™ counsel about the hearing in two letters, dated August 1, 2002 and 
    August 9, 2002.Â  The second letter specifically requested that any discovery 
    be completed prior to the hearing and offered to â€œaccommodate [counsel] in 
    any way to have any discovery accomplished prior to the hearing.â€Â  After a 
    request for continuance by Sandersâ€™ counsel, the hearing was rescheduled for 
    October 23, 2002.Â  
  The Clerk of Court sent notification of the new 
    hearing date to the parties on October 2, 2002. Â Sanders filed a Memorandum 
    in Opposition to the Motion for Summary Judgment on October 8, 2002, which 
    did not include any affidavits or supporting testimony.Â  Sanders did not send 
    a copy of the memorandum to Respondent.Â  Sandersâ€™ counsel also did not appear 
    at the October 23rd hearing.Â  The judge held that Respondent owed no duty 
    to the plaintiff and therefore did not breach any standard of care to the 
    plaintiff.
  Sanders filed a Motion for Reconsideration on 
    November 7, 2002, accompanied by a Memorandum in Support of Motion for Reconsideration.Â  
    The judge denied the Motion for Reconsideration based on the â€œdifferent standards 
    of care that are applicable and the evidence considered and arguments made 
    at the previous hearing.â€Â  Louise Wellington, as Sandersâ€™ Guardian 
    Ad Litem, now appeals.
  LAW/ANALYSIS
     I.         
    Notice
    Sanders maintains the circuit court erred in 
      finding proper notice had been given to him pursuant to Rules 5 and 6, SCRCP, 
      in regards to the October 23, 2002 hearing.Â  We disagree.
    Rules 5 and 6 of the South Carolina Rules of 
      Civil Procedure provide that for every written motion, notice of the hearing 
      must be served upon each of the parties through their attorney, if there 
      is one, by delivering a copy to him or by mailing it to him at his last 
      known address.Â  Rule 5(a) and (b)(1), SCRCP.Â  
    The Clerk of Court properly notified Sanders, 
      by mailing notice of the hearing to the most recent address on record for 
      Sandersâ€™ counsel.Â  Thus, service was proper.
     II.        
    Summary Judgment
    Sanders argues the circuit court erred in granting 
      summary judgment when discovery had not yet been completed.Â  We disagree.
    â€œ[S]ummary judgment must not be granted until 
      the opposing party has had a full and fair opportunity to complete discovery.â€Â  
      Baughman v. American Tel. & Tel., Co., 306 S.C. 101, 112, 410 
      S.E.2d 537, 543 (1991).Â  Summary judgment also should not be granted if 
      a party can demonstrate that further discovery will uncover additional evidence 
      relevant to the issue and that they are not merely engaged on a â€œfishing 
      expedition.â€Â  Id. at 112, 410 S.E.2d at 544.Â  Sanders neither requested 
      additional time from the court for discovery, nor proved that any extra 
      time would be beneficial to resolving the summary judgment motion.Â  In addition, 
      opposing counsel sent correspondence volunteering to help with any discovery 
      that needed to be completed before the hearing.Â  Therefore, Sanders had 
      a full and fair opportunity to complete discovery.
    Sanders also claims the circuit court erred 
      in granting summary judgment because, viewing the evidence in the light 
      most favorable to Sanders, material issues of fact exist regarding whether 
      Floyd or Manor House breached a duty of care to Sanders or proximately caused 
      Sandersâ€™ injuries.Â  We agree.
    On appeal of a grant of a summary judgment, 
      we apply the same standard that governs the trial court under Rule 56(c), 
      SCRCP:Â  summary judgment is proper when there is no genuine issue as to 
      any material fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter 
      of law.Â  Fleming v. Rose, 350 S.C. 488, 493, 567 S.E.2d 857, 860 
      (2002).Â  In determining whether an issue of fact exists, the evidence and 
      all inferences that can reasonably be drawn therefrom must be viewed in 
      the light most favorable to the nonmoving party.Â  Faile v. South Carolina 
      Depâ€™t of Juvenile Justice, 350 S.C. 315, 324, 566 S.E.2d 536, 540 (2002).Â  
      â€œSummary judgment is not appropriate where further inquiry into the facts 
      of the case is desirable to clarify the application of the law.â€Â  Vermeer 
      Carolinaâ€™s, Inc. v. Wood/Chuck Chipper Corp., 336 S.C. 53, 59, 518 S.E.2d 
      301, 306 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  â€œEven when there is no dispute as to evidentiary 
      facts, but only as to the conclusions or inferences to be drawn from them, 
      summary judgment should be denied.â€Â  Hall v. Fedor, 349 S.C. 169, 
      173-74, 561 S.E.2d 654, 656 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  Moreover, â€œ[s]ummary judgment 
      is a drastic remedy, which should be cautiously invoked so that no person 
      will be improperly deprived of a trial of the disputed factual issues.â€Â  
      Lanham v. Blue Cross and Blue Shield of South Carolina, Inc., 349 
      S.C. 356, 363, 563 S.E.2d 331, 336 (2002).
    Rule 56(e), SCRCP, states that a party opposing 
      a motion for summary judgment â€œmay not rest upon the mere allegations or 
      denials of his pleading.â€Â  The party must submit affidavits or the like, 
      which â€œset forth specific facts showing that there is a genuine issue for 
      trial.Â  If he does not so respond, summary judgment, if appropriate, shall 
      be entered against him.â€Â  Rule 56(e), SCRCP.
    In CEL Products, LLC v. Rozelle, this 
      court held an employer was entitled to summary judgment as to a former employeeâ€™s 
      claims because the former employee merely relied on his pleadings and did 
      not present opposing affidavits.Â  357 S.C. 125, 130, 591 S.E.2d 643, 645 
      (Ct. App. 2004).Â  When a plaintiff is faced with a defendantâ€™s motion for 
      summary judgment that is supported by evidence, the plaintiff cannot defeat 
      the motion by relying upon the mere allegations of his complaint, but must 
      disclose the facts he intends to rely on by affidavit or other proof.Â  Dyer 
      v. Moss, 284 S.C. 208, 211, 325 S.E.2d 69, 70 (Ct. App. 1995).Â  â€œA conclusory 
      statement as to the ultimate issue in a case is not sufficient to create 
      a genuine issue of fact for purposes of resisting summary judgment.â€Â  Shupe 
      v. Settle, 315 S.C. 510, 516-517, 445 S.E.2d 651, 655 (Ct. App. 1994).Â  
    
    However, â€œâ€˜[the] party opposing summary judgment 
      need not come forward in any way if the moving party has not supported his 
      motion to the point that it is a sham.â€™â€Â  Title Ins. Co. of Minnesota 
      v. Christian, 267 S.C. 71, 76, 226 S.E.2d 240, 242 (1976) (quoting Brunswick 
      Corp. v. Vineberg, 370 F.2d 605, 612 (5th Cir. 1967)).Â  â€œâ€˜Where the 
      evidentiary matter in support of the motion does not establish the absence 
      of a genuine issue, summary judgment must be denied, even if no opposing 
      evidentiary matter is presented.â€™â€Â  Id. (quoting Fed. R. Civ. P. 
      56).Â  The party moving for summary judgment carries the initial burden of 
      showing an absence of evidentiary support for the nonmoving partyâ€™s case.Â  
      NationsBank v. Scott Farm, 320 S.C. 299, 303, 465 S.E.2d 98, 100 
      (Ct. App. 1995).
    Although Sanders did not 
      offer any affidavits in opposition to Respondentâ€™s motion, Respondentâ€™s 
      evidentiary showing as to the issue of negligence fails to establish the 
      absence of a genuine issue.Â  Respondent maintains its contract with Sanders 
      provided that he was free to â€œcome and goâ€ as he pleased and submitted a 
      sworn affidavit prepared by Roberta Floyd denying she or Manor House had 
      a duty of care.Â  However, section 404 (c) of the South Carolina Code Regulations 
      61-84 (Supp. 2000) states:

    In cases where a resident 
      leaves the facility under circumstances which raise concerns about his/her 
      safety, the following must be contacted immediately: next of kin or responsible 
      person, sponsoring agency or any other agency providing services to the 
      client and local law enforcement.

    25A S.C.Code Ann.Regs. 61-84 
      (Supp. 2000).
    Whether Sanders left the 
      facility under circumstances that should have raised concern about his safety 
      is a genuine issue of material fact, therefore, the motion for summary judgment 
      should have been denied.Â  
    REVERSED AND REMANDED.
    STILWELL, BEATTY, and SHORT, JJ., concur.  

 
   [1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.

PER CURIAM:Â  Spartanburg 
  County grand jurors indicted Bruce Franklin Mathis for assault and battery, 
  failure to stop, and two counts of armed robbery.Â  At trial, Mathis requested 
  that the court instruct the jury on the elements of larceny as a lesser-included 
  offense of armed robbery.Â  The trial court refused, and the jury convicted Mathis 
  of all charges.Â  Mathis appeals on the ground that the trial court erred by 
  not instructing the jury on larceny.Â  We affirm pursuant to Rule 220(b)(2), 
  SCACR, and the following authorities:Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-11-330 (2003) (stating 
  a person is guilty of armed robbery if he â€œcommits robbery while armed with 
  a . . . deadly weaponâ€, or if he commits robbery â€œwhile alleging, either by 
  action or words, he [is] armed, while using a representation of a deadly weapon.â€); 
  State v. Keith, 283 S.C. 597, 598, 325 S.E.2d 325 (1985)

  to the contrary, the law will presume the instrument to be what his conduct 
  represents it to be.â€).Â  Â Â

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE

PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
David E. Steele, Respondent,
v.
Clara M. Steele, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Lancaster County
Â Walter B. Brown, Jr., Family Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-578Â Â Â 
Submitted October 1, 2004 â€“ Filed November 
  17, 2004 


AFFIRMED


  
    
      
G. RobinÂ  Alley, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Philip E. Wright, of Lancaster, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Clara M. Steele appeals from a family court order finding 
  her in contempt for destroying the plants, shrubs, and trees surrounding her 
  former marital home.Â  We affirm. [1] 
FACTS
Clara M. Steele (Wife) and David E. Steele (Husband) were divorced on March 
  27, 2003.Â  The settlement agreement, which was incorporated into the final order, 
  required Wife to vacate the marital home by April 15, 2003, at which time Husband 
  would pay her $5,000 for moving expenses.Â  Husband agreed to pay Wife $45,000 
  by May 15, 2003, and an additional $40,000 by April 1, 2007.Â  In the agreement, 
  the parties promised not to â€œdestroy or damage any real or personal property 
  of the other party.â€ 
After having been in exclusive physical possession of the marital home for 
  three years pending the final settlement of the partiesâ€™ property rights, Wife 
  vacated the home on April 15, 2003.Â  Husband entered the home the following 
  day.Â  Shortly after moving in, he noticed damage to the Yoshino cherry trees, 
  the most fragile plants in the yard.Â  He soon noticed a general decline in the 
  health of the other plants as well.Â  Thirteen days after Husband took possession 
  of the home, many of the plants around the house were dead or dying.Â  Pictures 
  of the damage showed that the plants within ten to fifteen feet of the house 
  had been completely destroyed.Â Â  
Husband brought a contempt action against Wife on May 16, 2003, alleging Wife 
  had damaged and destroyed plants, shrubs, and trees around the marital home.Â  
  He further requested to suspend payment of the $45,000 he owed Wife until the 
  contempt action was heard.Â  At the hearing, Husband testified as to his opinion 
  as a landscaper with a degree in horticulture and a holder of a South Carolina 
  pesticide license.Â  He believed that a chemical had been applied to the soil 
  and that the chemical would have residual effects.Â  To test this theory, Husband 
  planted new plants in the contaminated soil to see if they would survive.Â  The 
  new plants died almost immediately.Â  Husband also testified that he engaged 
  experts to help him document the damage and estimate the cost of repair. 
Husband believed Wife was responsible for the damage.Â  He pointed out that 
  Wife has a master gardener degree from Clemson University and is â€œfairly knowledgeable 
  on chemicals that could be used to contaminate soil.â€Â  Wifeâ€™s cousin and sister 
  testified for Husband, and both stated that Wife told them she would kill and 
  destroy all the plants around the house if she had to move from the marital 
  home.Â  In response, Wife presented testimony that she was not close to her sister 
  or cousin and she would not tell them such damaging information.Â  Wifeâ€™s daughter 
  and another cousin testified that Wife had never mentioned destroying any plants 
  around the house.Â Â  
The family court held Wife in contempt and ordered Husband to engage the services 
  of a licensed contractor to return the property as close as possible to its 
  condition on April 15, 2003.Â  The court ordered that Wife would bear the cost 
  of removing any contaminated soil and replacing all the plants that were destroyed.Â  
  The court further found Wife should pay Husbandâ€™s attorneyâ€™s fees and costs, 
  totaling $1,000.Â  Both the cost of restoring the property and the attorneyâ€™s 
  fees were to be deducted from the $45,000 Husband owed Wife.Â Â  
Pursuant to Wifeâ€™s motion for reconsideration, the court modified the contempt 
  order as it related to damages.Â  The amended order required each party to obtain 
  an estimate for removing the soil and replacing the plants.Â  The parties were 
  directed to attempt to come to an agreement on the cost of restoring the property.Â  
  If an agreement could not be reached, a subsequent hearing would be scheduled 
  to determine the measure of damages.Â  Wife appeals.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Although a determination of contempt is within the family courtâ€™s discretion, 
  an order holding a party in contempt â€œshould be reversed when the holding is 
  based on a finding that is without evidentiary support or when there is . . 
  . an abuse of discretion.â€Â  Means v. Means, 277 S.C. 428, 431, 288 S.E.2d 
  811, 812-13 (1982).Â  To sustain a finding of contempt, the record must be clear 
  and specific as to acts or conduct upon which the finding is based.Â  See 
  Curlee v. Howle, 277 S.C. 377, 382, 287 S.E.2d 915, 918 (1982).
LAW/ ANALYSIS
Wife maintains the family court erred in holding her in contempt of a prior 
  court order because the finding is without evidentiary support.Â  We disagree.
Upon moving into the home, Husband immediately started noticing problems with 
  the plants, shrubs, and trees on the property.Â  As stated above, a mere thirteen 
  days later almost everything, including the grass surrounding certain plants, 
  was dead or dying.Â  In Husbandâ€™s opinion as a landscaper and licensed pesticide 
  applicator, the soil had been directly contaminated.Â  He tested his theory by 
  planting new tomato plants, all of which died over a two-week period.Â Â  Furthermore, 
  Husband testified that the rain totals for the year had been â€œmore than sufficient.â€Â  

Additionally, Wife is a master gardener and has some knowledge of chemicals.Â  
  She also had direct, unfettered access to the house.Â  In contrast, Husband testified 
  that he once had to be escorted to the property by a deputy sheriff to view 
  a roof in need of repair so Wife would not shoot at him. 
Most importantly, Shelby Jean Taylor, Wifeâ€™s first cousin, testified that Wife 
  said on several occasions that â€œshe was going to kill everything around [the 
  house].â€Â  Wifeâ€™s sister, Samantha Ann Roads, testified that, following their 
  motherâ€™s death, Wife â€œsaid that if she had to move from the house, had to leave 
  the house, that she would kill and destroy all the plants around the house.â€Â  
  Though Wifeâ€™s daughter and Wifeâ€™s cousin, Joyce Snipes, both testified that 
  Wife had a strained relationship with Husbandâ€™s witnesses and would never have 
  used them as confidantes, Snipesâ€™ testimony contradicted Wifeâ€™s.Â  Snipes claimed 
  that Wife and Husbandâ€™s witnesses had not spoken since the funeral of Wifeâ€™s 
  mother.Â  However, Wife admitted she saw Taylor and her sister once a month since 
  her mother passed away.Â  
Based on the testimony of the witnesses, we find there is evidence in the record 
  from which the family court could find that Wife destroyed the plants surrounding 
  the marital home.Â  Therefore, the family court did not abuse its discretion 
  by holding Wife in contempt of its previous order. 
Wife next maintains the family court erred by awarding damages to Husband because 
  the damages were speculative in nature and based entirely on conjecture.Â  We 
  disagree.
According to the order dated July 25, 2003, the parties each must acquire one 
  estimate on the cost of â€œremoval of the contaminated soil and replacement of 
  the plants, which were destroyed.â€Â  If they cannot agree on a price to replace 
  the plants, the family court â€œshall schedule a hearing . . . to determine the 
  measure of damages.â€Â Â  Thus, damages have yet to be awarded.Â  Because the family

Reginald L. Foster, of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  This declaratory judgment action concerns excess liability 
  insurance coverage.Â  South Carolina Farm Bureau Mutual Insurance Company 
  filed this action to determine whether it had any excess liability coverage 
  for an accident involving Tracey Moore, Becky Smith, and Barry Smith. At the 
  time of the accident, Tracey Moore was driving an Isuzu Trooper owned by her 
  mother-in-law and insured by Farm Bureau.Â  Tracy Mooreâ€™s husband, Stephen Moore, 
  owned a truck also insured by Farm Bureau.Â  Farm Bureau, as insurer of the Isuzu, 
  paid its policy limits to the Smiths and brought suit to determine whether its 
  policy on Stephen Mooreâ€™s truck provided excess liability coverage that would 
  be available to the Smiths.Â  The trial judge, sitting without a jury, determined 
  Farm Bureau did not provide excess coverage because Stephen Mooreâ€™s policy contained 
  a â€œregular use exclusionâ€ and the Isuzu was â€œavailable for the regular useâ€ 
  of Tracey Moore.Â  The Smiths appeal.Â  We affirm. 
  [1] 
The Smiths argue the Isuzu was not available for the regular use of Tracy Moore 
  as defined by the Farm Bureau policy.Â  
â€œOn appeal of an action at law tried by the judge without a jury this court 
  will review the factual findings to determine if there is any evidence to support 
  them.â€ Â South Carolina Farm Bureau Mut. Ins. Co. v. Windham, 303 
  S.C. 330, 331, 400 S.E.2d 497 (Ct. App. 1990).Â  Evidence presented in this case 
  includes Farm Bureauâ€™s exclusionary provision and Tracey Mooreâ€™s deposition 
  testimony.
The Farm Bureau policy excluded liability for non-owned vehicles available 
  for the â€œregular use of the insured.â€Â  The purpose of a regular use provision 
  is â€œto afford coverage for the infrequent and casual use of vehicles other than 
  the one described in the policy, but not to cover the insured with respect to 
  his use of another vehicle which he frequently uses or has the opportunity to 
  use.â€Â  AETNA Cas. & Sur. v. Sessions, et al., 260 S.C. 150, 155, 
  194 S.E.2d 877, 879 (1973).Â  â€œRegular useâ€ is be distinguished from casual, 
  occasional, or infrequent use.Â  Grantham v. U.S. Fidelity and Guar. Co., 
  245 S.C. 144, 149, 139 S.E.2d 744, 746 (1964).Â  
The trial judge found as fact that the Isuzu was available for the regular 
  use of Tracey Moore.Â  Evidence in the record supports this finding.Â  In her 
  deposition, Tracey Moore stated she had a set of keys for the Isuzu, she kept 
  the Isuzu at her house â€œhalf of the time,â€ and she could use the vehicle for 
  any purpose.Â  The Isuzu was Tracey Mooreâ€™s primary means of transportation while 
  Stephen Moore was at work.Â  In addition, the declarations page of the insurance 
  policy on the Isuzu listed Tracy Moore as a driver. 
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., GOOLSBY and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

    to Rule 215, SCACR.

v.
Latorey J. Green, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Sumter County
Â Howard P. King, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-581
Submitted October 1, 2004 â€“ Filed November 
  17, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Aileen P. Clare, Office of Appellate Defense, of 
  Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. 
  McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott,
Â Senior Assistant Attorney 
  General Harold M. Coombs, Jr., all of Columbia; and Solicitor Cecil Kelley Jackson, 
  of Sumter, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Latorey J. Greene was convicted of first-degree criminal 
  sexual conduct, first-degree burglary, and assault and battery of a high and 
  aggravated nature.Â  He appeals, arguing the trial court abused its discretion 
  by allowing the solicitor to impeach him with his juvenile adjudication for 
  criminal sexual conduct with a minor.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
On July 11, 1998, Greene and the victim were partying at a mutual friendâ€™s 
  home.Â  The victim admitted she was drinking alcohol and using crack cocaine 
  â€œoff and onâ€ all day.Â  Late that evening, the victim testified that Greene offered 
  her a ride home, which she accepted.Â  She explained that she trusted Greene 
  to bring her home because she had dated his uncle in the past and thought of 
  Greene as a nephew.Â  When Greene brought the victim home, a cousin of Greeneâ€™s, 
  Christopher Billie, came along.Â  
The victim testified that both Greene and Billie walked her inside.Â  She claimed 
  that Greene made unwanted sexual advances toward her, which she fought off.Â  
  Billie heard the commotion, talked to Greene, and the two men left the victimâ€™s 
  home.Â  After they left, the victim locked her front door and the door to her 
  bedroom, and she went to bed.Â  She fell asleep on her stomach and later woke 
  up when she realized that a man was on her back, raping her.Â  After ejaculating 
  inside her, the man left, and though the victim never saw his face, she recognized 
  that he was wearing the same tennis shoes that Greene had been wearing earlier 
  that night.
The victim waited for about five minutes before she dressed and ran to a nearby 
  pay phone.Â  She called 911, reported the rape, and was transported by ambulance 
  to the hospital.Â  At the hospital, a sample of semen was taken from her underwear.Â Â  
  The DNA of the semen matched the DNA of a blood sample Greene gave to investigators.Â  
  Â Â 
After the State rested its case against Greene, defense counsel explained that 
  Greene was planning to testify on his own behalf and made a motion to prevent 
  the solicitor from revealing to the jury Greeneâ€™s juvenile adjudication for 
  criminal sexual conduct with a minor.Â  The trial court determined that because 
  the past conviction was within the past ten years and the convictionâ€™s probative 
  value outweighed its prejudicial effect, the conviction could be used to impeach 
  Greeneâ€™s credibility.Â  
Greene claimed that he and the victim had known each other for years and that 
  they had had sex in the past.Â Â  He described the victim as a long-time crack 
  addict who would have sex in exchange for drugs or money.Â  On the night he is 
  accused of raping the victim, Greene testified that the victim asked him for 
  a ride home and told him she would have sex with him if he paid her $20.Â  Greene 
  claims he gave the victim $20, and the two had consensual sex.Â  
After deliberating for over twelve hours, the jury found Greene guilty of all 
  charges.Â  Greene was sentenced to concurrent terms of confinement totaling thirty-five 
  years.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The decision to admit prior convictions to impeach a defendantâ€™s credibility 
  is a matter left to the sound discretion of the trial court, and absent an abuse 
  of discretion, the appellate courts will not reverse that decision.Â Â Â Â  Green 
  v. State, 338 S.C. 428, 433, 527 S.E.2d 98, 101 (2000).Â  To amount to an 
  abuse of discretion, the trial courtâ€™s conclusions must either lack evidentiary 
  support or be controlled by an error of law.Â  State v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 
  1, 5-6, 545 S.E.2d 827, 829 (2001).Â  
Rule 609(d), SCRE, provides that juvenile adjudications can be used to impeach 
  the accused when the crime adjudicated would be admissible to attack the credibility 
  of an adult.Â  Pursuant to subsections (a)(1) and (b) of Rule 609, a crime is 
  admissible to attack the credibility of an adult when: (1) the crime was punishable 
  by death or imprisonment in excess of one year, (2) the probative value of the 
  prior crime outweighs its prejudicial effect, and (3) the prior conviction is 
  less than ten years old. [1] Â  
  When weighing the probative value of the defendantâ€™s prior convictions, the 
  trial court should consider the impeachment value of the prior crime, the amount 
  of time between the conviction and the defendantâ€™s subsequent history, the similarity 
  between the past conviction and the present charge, the importance of the defendantâ€™s 
  testimony, and the centrality of the credibility issue.Â  Green, 338 S.C. 
  at 433, 527 S.E.2d at 101.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Greene argues the trial 
  court erred by allowing the solicitor to impeach him with his juvenile adjudication 
  for criminal sexual conduct with a minor.Â  This issue is not preserved for review. 

At the close of the Stateâ€™s case, defense counsel explained 
  that Greene planned to take the stand in his own defense and made a motion requesting 
  that the solicitor not be allowed to impeach Greene on his juvenile adjudication 
  for criminal sexual conduct.Â  Specifically, Greeneâ€™s counsel stated: â€œI would 
  make a motion at this time in limine that they not be allowed to go into [Greeneâ€™s] 
  juvenile record.â€Â  The trial court denied the motion, and the following colloquy 
  then took place:

DEFENSE COUNSEL: Unless you can tell me that I can preserve this and still ask 
  [Greene] about the juvenile record on direct I will simply ask him about his 
  adult record and Iâ€™m sure [the solicitor] will bring out the juvenile . . . 
  unless you allow me to preserve it and still ask the question.
TRIAL COURT: I donâ€™t know if I can or not.Â  I donâ€™t know that I have that authority.Â  
  I think youâ€™ll have to just do it whatever way you want to do it and I . . . 
  you know, I canâ€™t say that your objection when you bring it out . . . thatâ€™s 
  going to be the ruling when the question is asked.Â  And you can handle it 
  anyway that you want to.

(Emphasis added.) 
The defense then proceeded with its case, first calling Greeneâ€™s cousin, Christopher 
  Billie, to the stand.Â  After Billieâ€™s testimony, Greene testified on his own 
  behalf.Â  During cross-examination, the solicitor asked Greene if he was convicted 
  for criminal sexual conduct in 1993.Â  Defense counsel did not object to the 
  question, and Greene admitted to having this prior conviction.Â  
Despite defense counselâ€™s own characterization of his motion to exclude Greeneâ€™s 
  juvenile record, it was not a motion in limine because it was made after 
  the trial had begun.Â  State v. Mueller, 319 S.C. 266, 269 n.1, 460 S.E.2d 
  409, 410 n.1 (Ct. App. 1995) (â€œA motion in limine is a pretrial procedure[.]â€). 
  However, like an in limine motion, the purpose of defense counselâ€™s motion 
  was to receive a preliminary ruling that would prevent the disclosure of a prejudicial 
  matter to the jury.Â  See, e.g., State v. Floyd, 295 S.C. 
  518, 369 S.E.2d 842 (1988) (explaining that the purpose of a motion in limine 
  is to prevent the disclosure of a potentially prejudicial matter to the jury). 
  Because the ruling was preliminary, it was subject to change based on developments 
  at trial.Â  Had no evidence been presented between the time of the trial courtâ€™s 
  ruling and the presentation of the objectionable evidence, then no contemporaneous 
  objection would be needed to preserve the issue for appeal.Â  State v. Forrester, 
  343 S.C. 637, 642, 541 S.E.2d 837, 840 (2001) (finding no contemporaneous objection 
  was necessary because the trial court had denied the motion in limine 
  immediately before the witness testified). However, because the trial court 
  heard the direct and cross examination of the defendantâ€™s cousin and the direct 
  testimony of Greene before the objectionable testimony was elicited by the solicitor, 
  defense counsel needed to make a contemporaneous objection to allow the trial 
  court to make a final ruling on the issue.Â  State v. Simpson, 325 S.C. 
  37, 42, 479 S.E.2d 57, 60 (1996).Â  Because no objection was made when the solicitor 
  questioned Greene about his juvenile adjudication, the issue of whether the 
  trial court erred in allowing Greeneâ€™s record to be admitted is not preserved 
  for our review.Â  Accordingly, Greeneâ€™s convictions are
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., HUFF and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1]  A conviction that is greater than ten years old may be admitted if 
    the defendantâ€™s release from prison was within the last ten years or when 
    the court finds â€œin the interests of justice, that the probative value of 
    the conviction supported by specific facts and circumstances substantially 
    outweighs its prejudicial effect.â€Â  Rule 609(b), SCRE.

of the respondent Mercury Finance Company against t

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

v.
Mercury Finance Company of South Carolina and Travelers Rest Cars-Trucks,
LLC, Defendants,
Of Whom Mercury Finance Company of South Carolina is the
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â Larry R. Patterson, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-582
Submitted November 1, 2004 â€“ Filed November 
  17, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Michael Stephen Chambers, of Greenville, for Appellant.
A.M. Quattlebaum, Jr. and Peter G. Siachos, both of Greenville, 
  for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  This is an appeal from the grant of summary judgment in 
  favor of the respondent Mercury Finance Company against the appellant Donald 
  C. Bedford.Â  We affirm. [1] 
Bedford purchased a 1997 Chevrolet pickup truck on September 14, 2000, from 
  the defendant Travelers Rest Cars-Trucks, LLC.Â  On March 16, 2001, Bedfordâ€™s 
  attorney wrote Mercury Finance a letter advising that Bedford â€œrescinds the 
  transactionâ€ and â€œwill retain possession of the auto [sic] as security 
  for the return of . . . paymentsâ€ that Bedford had made on the vehicle.Â  Mercury 
  Finance repossessed the truck on May 4, 2001.Â  
This action ensued with Bedfordâ€™s complaint alleging causes of action for conversion, 
  violation of the Federal Truth-in-Lending Act, violation of the South Carolina 
  Consumer Protection Code, fraud, rescission, violation of the Unfair Trade Practices 
  Act, and violation of the Regulation of Manufacturers, Distributors, and Dealers 
  Act.Â  
According to Bedfordâ€™s brief, â€œ[t]he gravamen of [his] claim is that he was 
  not made aware of the monthly payments required under the transactionsâ€ and 
  â€œ[t]his is the direct result of the failure to provide [him] with a copy of 
  the required disclosures.â€Â  This â€œ[f]ailure,â€ he says, â€œconstitutes a material 
  misrepresentation and inducement by unconscionable conduct, warranting revocation 
  of acceptance.â€Â  
The trial court granted summary judgment to Mercury Finance on all causes of 
  action.Â  It found that Mercury Finance provided Bedford with all disclosure 
  forms required by the Federal Truth-in-Lending Act, 15 U.S.C.A. Â§Â§ 1601 et 
  seq. (1998) [hereinafter, â€œthe Actâ€].Â  
The grant of summary judgment came after Mercury Finance had served Bedford 
  on June 19, 2001, with interrogatories, requests for production of documents, 
  and requests for admissions, and moved on February 4, 2002 to compel Bedford 
  to answer its interrogatories and respond to its requests for production of 
  documents that Bedford had ignored.Â  The trial court had granted Mercury Financeâ€™s 
  motion to compel, ordering Bedford to answer all outstanding discovery requests 
  within ten days or by March 31, 2002. Â Notwithstanding the fact that 
  almost ten months had passed since Mercury Finance had served its discovery 
  upon Bedford, he had waited until April 4, 2002, to respond to Mercury Financeâ€™s 
  requests for admission, missing the court-imposed deadline by four days.Â  
When reviewing the grant of summary judgment by a trial court, the court of 
  appeals will apply the same standard used by the trial court under Rule 56(c), 
  SCRCP, in considering it.Â  That is, summary judgment will be held proper when 
  there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and the moving party is entitled 
  to judgment as a matter of law.Â  Baril v. Aiken Regâ€™l Med. Ctrs., 352 
  S.C. 271, 279-80, 573 S.E.2d 830, 835 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  Furthermore, â€œ[w]hen 
  a plaintiff is faced with a defendantâ€™s motion for summary judgment that is 
  supported by evidence, the plaintiff cannot defeat the motion by relying upon 
  the mere allegations of his complaint, but must disclose the facts he intends 
  to rely on by affidavit or other proof.â€Â  Shupe v. Settle, 315 S.C. 510, 
  516, 445 S.E.2d 651, 655 (Ct. App. 1994).Â  The facts presented and all reasonable 
  inferences that may be drawn from them must be viewed in the light most favorable 
  to the nonmoving party.Â  Englert, Inc. v. Netherlands Ins. Co., 315 S.C. 
  300, 302, 433 S.E.2d 871, 873 (Ct. App. 1993). 
Under the Act, the term â€œmaterial disclosuresâ€ means, among other things, â€œthe 
  disclosure, as required by this subchapter [15 U.S.C.A. Â§Â§ 1601 et seq. 
  (1998)], of . . . the total of payments, the number of and amount of payments, 
  . . . to repay the indebtedness.â€Â  15 U.S.C.A. Â§ 1602(u) (1998).
We agree with the trial court that no genuine issue of material fact exists 
  regarding whether Bedford was provided with a disclosure form that told him 
  of the amount of the monthly payments that the transaction in question required 
  him to make.Â  The record contains a document entitled â€œRETAIL INSTALLMENT CONTRACTâ€”AUTO 
  (including Truth in Lending Disclosures) SOUTH CAROLINA.â€Â  The document includes 
  a box whose heading reads, â€œTRUTH IN LENDING DISCLOSURES.â€ Within the box are 
  smaller ones that disclose, among other things, the total of payments, the number 
  of payments, and the amount of payments required to repay the indebtedness. [2] Â  A signature, that Bedford conceded at his deposition resembled 
  his own and at no time challenged, appears below a statement that reads, â€œBuyer 
  hereby acknowledges receipt of an exact and completely filled in copy of this 
  contract at the time of its execution.â€Â Â Â  
Moreover, Bedford is deemed under Rule 36(a), SCRCP, to have admitted he signed 
  the Retail Installment Contract after he failed to respond timely to Mercury 
  Financeâ€™s requests for admission, particularly the statements â€œ[t]hat [Bedford] 
  signed the Retail Installment Contractâ€ and â€œ[t]hat the Retail Installment Contract 
  . . . contains all the disclosures required by law.â€Â  Even if the trial courtâ€™s 
  order compelling discovery is viewed as allowing Bedford an additional ten days 
  to respond to Mercury Financeâ€™s request for admission, Bedford failed to meet 
  that deadline as well. [3] Â  Under 
  Rule 36(b), SCRCP, the admitted matters were deemed â€œconclusively establishedâ€ 
  since Bedford never asked to withdraw or amend his admissions and the trial 
  court never allowed him to do so. 
  [4]   
Because we hold 
  the trial court did not err in granting summary judgment to Mercury Finance 
  on the issue of whether it provided Bedford with a proper truth-in-lending document, 
  we need not address the question of whether Bedford lawfully revoked his acceptance 
  of the pickup under the Uniform Commercial Code, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 36-2-608 (2003).
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., GOOLSBY and WILLIAMS, JJ. concur

 
   
    [1] Â  This case is decided without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, 
    SCACR.

 
   
    [2] Â Â  The monthly payments were listed as being $358.86.Â  He admitted 
    during his deposition that he made five or six payments of approximately $360 
    a month. 

 
   
    [3] Â  The trial courtâ€™s order regarding discovery came in response to 
    a motion by Mercury Finance to compel Bedford to answer its interrogatories 
    and respond to its requests for production of documents.Â  The trial court 
    gave Bedford â€œ10 days to fully answer all outstanding discovery requests.â€Â  
  

 
   
    [4] Â Â  The trial court rightly ignored the affidavit Bedford executed 
    in which he swore he â€œwas not provided with a Truth in Lending Disclosure 
    Statementâ€ and he did â€œnot recall signing a Truth in Lending Disclosure Statement.â€Â  
    A party cannot create a genuine issue of material fact in an effort to survive 
    a motion for summary judgment by submitting an affidavit that contradicts 
    a conclusively-established admitted fact.Â  See United States v. 
    Kasuboski, 834 F.2d 1345, 1350 (7th Cir. 1987) (holding affidavits 
    entered into opposition to a motion for summary judgment in an attempt to 
    establish issues of fact could not refute issues of fact established by default 
    admissions); cf. Scott v. Greenville Housing, 353 S.C. 639, 
    646, 579 S.E.2d 151, 155 (Ct. App. 2003) (holding that the tenets of Rule 
    36(a), SCRCP, regard a failure to respond to requests for admission deems 
    the matter contained in the requests as admitted); Hatchell v. Jackson, 
    290 S.C. 256, 258, 349 S.E.2d 407, 408 (Ct. App. 1986) (holding a failure 
    of a party to respond to another partyâ€™s requests for admission had the effect 
    of deeming each matter regarding which the other party sought an admission 
    to be admitted under Rule 36(a), SCRCP).

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Rudolph Lee Smith,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Robin Smith,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Dorchester County
William J. Wylie, Jr., Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-588
Submitted October 1, 2004 â€“ Filed November 29, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Susan Trout Kinard, of Mt. Pleasant, for Appellant.
Donna K. Taylor, and Susan King Dunn, both of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this divorce case, Robin Smith (â€œWifeâ€) asserts on appeal that the family court erred in: equitably apportioning the marital property; accepting Rudolph Lee Smithâ€™s (â€œHusbandâ€) valuations of property; failing to value certain property before apportionment; and granting Husband a divorce based upon adultery.Â  We affirm the order of the family court.[1]Â Â  
FACTS
Husband and Wife were married in 1974, when Wife was 16 and Husband was 19.Â  The marriage produced two sons.Â  The oldest is emancipated.Â  Custody of the youngest, Alex, has been shared between the parents since April 2000.Â  
At the beginning of the marriage, Wife finished high school, cared for the home and children, and worked at part-time, minimum wage jobs.Â  Husband dropped out of high school in the ninth grade and received no further education.Â  Husband has been employed full-time in construction for the duration of the marriage except for two periods when he was unable to work due to injury.Â Â Â  
In 1981, Wife joined the Air Force Reserves.Â  In 1991, Wife obtained full-time employment as a civil servant with the Reserves.Â  Wife accrued Air Force Reserve Retirement benefits during this time.Â  Before Wife was employed full-time, she earned less money than Husband.Â  Husband testified that her income had been roughly the same as his since she began working as a civil servant.Â  Wife testified that her income was less than Husbandâ€™s when she first began to work full-time.Â  It is undisputed, however, that Wife earned at least as much as Husband during the last five years of the marriage, and that her income exceeded Husbandâ€™s by $1,000 per month at the time of trial.Â Â  
During the marriage the couple opened a checking account.Â  Each deposited an equal amount of approximately $500 every two weeks.Â  All household expenses were paid from this account.Â  Funds in the account were used to purchase a mobile home, the marital lot, and real property in White Hall.Â  Any money not placed in the account remained in the possession of the earner.Â  Husband used his extra funds to invest in stocks, IRAâ€™s, and real property.Â  Wife used her funds to purchase a car, clothing, and food.Â  She also spent $4,000 of her funds on liposuction and breast enhancement.Â  
The breakup of the marriage occurred on October 31, 1999.Â  Wife had previously asked to separate, but Husband did not agree until she returned from a weekend trip with a new negligee and an unopened box of condoms in her suitcase.Â  Wife testified that these items were meant to test her husband, but the family court found the testimony was not credible.Â  Wife left the marital home that night and did not return.Â  
In April of 2000, Wife filed an action for separate support and maintenance.Â  Husband answered and counterclaimed.Â  He also requested an order for separate support.Â  A pendente lite order was issued on May 30, 2000.Â  
In October 2000, Husband filed a separate action for divorce on the ground of adultery and sought equitable distribution of the partiesâ€™ property.Â  Wife filed an answer and counterclaim, raising the affirmative defense of recrimination.Â  The two cases were consolidated for trial.
The parties stipulated to the values of the liquid marital assets, the mobile home, the White Hall lot, and the cemetery plots.Â  The value of the marital lot, the Georgia property, and the two automobiles were in dispute.Â  The couple also owned three time-shares, but neither offered any evidence as to value.Â  The amount of marital debt was also contested.Â  At issue at trial was the value of the contested items and how they were to be apportioned between the parties.Â Â Â  
The family court granted Husband a divorce on the ground of adultery.Â  Wife was awarded 35% of the marital assets, and Husband was awarded 65% of the assets.Â  Husband was also awarded 65% of Wifeâ€™s Air Force Reserve Retirement account accrued during the marriage.Â  Neither party made any post-trial motions.Â  Wife appeals the family courtâ€™s order.Â Â Â Â Â Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In appeals from family courts, we have jurisdiction to find the facts in accordance with our own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Rutherford v. Rutherford, 307 S.C. 199, 204, 414 S.E.2d 157, 160 (1992).Â  This broad scope of review does not, however, require this court to disregard the findings of the family court.Â  Stevenson v. Stevenson, 276 S.C. 475, 477, 279 S.E.2d 616, 617 (1981).Â  Neither is the court required to ignore the fact that the family court judge, who saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better position to evaluate their credibility and assign comparative weight to their testimony.Â  Cherry v. Thomasson, 276 S.C. 524, 525, 280 S.E.2d 541, 541 (1981).Â  Further, the equitable apportionment of marital property rests with the sound discretion of the family court judge, whose conclusion will not be disturbed absent a showing of abuse of discretion.Â  Rogers v. Rogers, 280 S.C. 205, 207, 311 S.E.2d 743, 744 (Ct. App. 1984).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I. EQUITABLE APPORTIONMENT
Wife contends the family court abused its discretion and committed an error of law in awarding her only 35% of the marital estate because the court did not consider all the factors and erred in considering her adultery and economic misconduct.Â  She also asserts the court erred in awarding Husband 65% of her military retirement benefits earned during the marriage.Â  We disagree.Â  
Section 20-7-472 lists fifteen factors for the court to consider in equitably apportioning a marital estate.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-472 (Supp. 2003); Greene v. Greene, 351 S.C. 329, 340, 569 S.E.2d 393, 399 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  When reviewing the family courtâ€™s equitable apportionment, â€œthis Court looks to the fairness of the overall apportionment.Â  If the end result is equitable, it is irrelevant that this Court might have weighed specific factors differently than the trial judge.â€Â  Johnson v. Johnson, 296 S.C. 289, 300, 372 S.E.2d 107, 113 (Ct. App. 1988) (citations omitted).Â  The family courtâ€™s apportionment of marital property will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Bragg v. Bragg, 347 S.C. 16, 23, 553 S.E.2d 251, 255 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  â€œThis court will affirm the family court judge if it can be determined that the judge addressed the factors under section 20-7-472 sufficiently for us to conclude he was cognizant of the statutory factors.â€ Jenkins v. Jenkins, 345 S.C. 88, 100, 545 S.E.2d 531, 537 (Ct. App. 2001).
A. Adultery
Wife testified at trial that she wanted to separate from Husband and date other people, and he suggested they continue to live together.Â  She stated that when she was returning from a weekend trip, she placed a new negligee, with store tags still attached, and an unopened box of condoms in her suitcase.Â  She wanted Husband to see these items to â€œtestâ€ whether he was sincere in his declaration that she could live in the marital home but date other people.Â  Wife stated that she did not begin a sexual relationship with another man until August 2000, which was two months after the pendente lite order.Â  Husband obtained evidence of this relationship in September 2000 by hiring a private investigator to follow Wife.Â  This evidence was introduced at trial.Â  
In the final order, the family court found Wifeâ€™s explanation of the negligee and condom was not credible and that she had the opportunity and the inclination to commit adultery.Â  The court also noted the date of the partiesâ€™ marriage, Husbandâ€™s prudent investments, Wifeâ€™s economic misconduct, the value of the marital property, the partiesâ€™ earning capacities, various retirement funds the partiesâ€™ owned, and marital debt.Â  The final order noted that the family court considered all the factors found in section 20-7-472, particularly Wifeâ€™s fault in the break-up of the marriage and her economic misconduct.Â  
Citing South Carolina Code section 20-7-472(2)(a), Wife argues the family court erred in considering adultery as a reason to punish her in the division of the marital estate because the only proof at trial was of a relationship commencing after the pendente lite order.Â  Section 20-7-472(2)(a) provides that evidence of personal misconduct, which would normally be relevant in equitably dividing martial property, shall not be considered in the division â€œif such conduct shall have taken place subsequent to the happening of . . . entry of a pendente lite order in a divorce or separate maintenance action . . . .â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-472(2)(a) (Supp. 2003).Â  
While Wife is correct that family courts in general should not consider adultery after the pendente lite order in equitably dividing the property, nothing in the record indicates that Wife raised this issue before the family court in a post-trial motion.Â  Accordingly, this issue is not preserved for our review.Â  See McDavid v. McDavid, 333 S.C. 490, 497, 511 S.E.2d 365, 368-69 (1999) (holding an issue not raised to or ruled on by the family court should not be considered by the appellate court).Â  
In any event, the negligee incident, occurring after Wife asked to separate from Husband and after she went away for a weekend, was evidence supporting the family courtâ€™s finding of opportunity and inclination to commit adultery during the marriage.Â  We find no abuse of discretion in the consideration of adultery in dividing the marital estate.
B. Economic misconduct
Wife complains the family court erred in considering her spending habits in dividing the marital property.Â  Although the parties contributed to a family fund and each invested their remaining money as they saw fit, Wife spent her money on clothes, shoes, liposuction, breast enhancement, and trips.Â  Evidence at trial indicated Wifeâ€™s clothes and shoes filled a garage such that a car could not pull into the garage.Â  Husband testified he invested money for the coupleâ€™s future in IRAs, CDs, BellSouth stocks, and real property in Georgia.Â  Thus, the family courtâ€™s finding that Wife was guilty of economic misconduct while Husband invested wisely is supported by the record.Â  Further, Wife failed to raise the consideration of economic misconduct to the family court in a post-trial motion.Â  Thus, this issue is not preserved for appellate review.Â  McDavid, 333 S.C. at 497, 511 S.E.2d at 368-69.
C. Award of military retirement benefits
Wife argues the family court erred in awarding Husband 65% of her Air Force Reserve Retirement benefits accrued during the partiesâ€™ marriage.Â  
Wife is correct in her allegation that 65% of her retirement benefits should not be awarded to Husband.Â  The Uniformed Services Former Spouseâ€™s Protection Act (USFSPA) provides that no more than 50% of a memberâ€™s military retirement pay can be ordered to be paid to the memberâ€™s former spouse in a divorce or separate maintenance order.Â  10 U.S.C.A. Â§ 1408(e)(1) (1998); see Coon v. Coon, 356 S.C. 342, 351, 588 S.E.2d 624, 629 (Ct. App. 2003), cert. granted (Oct. 6, 2004) (noting that the USFSPA limits the family courtâ€™s authority to award more than 50% of military retirement benefits, but it does not infringe upon its subject matter jurisdiction).Â  However, Wife stipulated that Husband was entitled to a portion of her military retirement benefits at trial, and she failed to object to the percentage awarded in a post-trial motion.Â  Accordingly, this issue is not preserved for appellate review.Â  McDavid, 333 S.C. at 497, 511 S.E.2d at 368-69.
D. Consideration of factors
Wife finally argues the family court failed to adequately consider all the factors in equitably distributing the marital estate.Â  
A family court must consider fifteen factors in equitably dividing marital property:Â  (1) the length of the marriage and the ages of the parties; (2) the martial misconduct of either party; (3) the value of the marital property; (4) the income and earning potential of each spouse; (5) each partyâ€™s emotional and physical health; (6) the need of a spouse for training to reach his or her earning potential; (7) each partyâ€™s nonmarital property; (8) retirement benefits; (9) awards of alimony; (10) whether the marital home should be awarded to one spouse; (11) the tax consequences of a particular distribution; (12) the existence of support obligations from prior marriage; (13) liens or encumbrances on marital property and any debt; (14) child custody arrangements; and (15) any other relevant factor the trial court enumerates in the order.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-472 (Supp. 2003).
The evidence indicates the family court adequately considered all the statutory factors in equitably dividing the marital assets and debts.Â  The final order noted the length of the marriage, the marital misconduct of Wife, Husbandâ€™s prudent investments, Wifeâ€™s economic misconduct, the value of the marital property, the partiesâ€™ earning capacities, various retirement funds the partiesâ€™ owned, and marital debt.Â  The order specified that the family court considered the fifteen factors found in section 20-7-472.Â  Although the parties in the present case had a long marriage and each party contributed financially to the marriage, we find, based on the factors considered by the family court, that the actual distribution of assets and debts was equitable in this case.Â  
II. VALUATION OF PROPERTY AND DEBT
Wife next argues the family court erred in adopting Husbandâ€™s property and debt valuations, failed to value other property before apportionment, and made a mathematical error when it distributed the property.Â  We find no error.
A.Â  Adopting Husbandâ€™s valuations
There was conflicting testimony as to the value of the marital lot and the real property located in Georgia.Â  Husband submitted the 2000 tax assessment for the marital lot that valued the property at $11,000.Â  Wife testified that sales figures from comparable lots in the neighborhood indicated that the lot had a value of between $16,000 and $17,000.Â  The value of the real property located in Georgia was also in dispute.Â  Husband submitted a tax assessorâ€™s notice that showed the fair market value of the lot at $20,000.Â  Wife testified that the property was worth $32,000.Â  Each asserted that the value proffered was the value on the date of the commencement of the action.
In both instances the family court relied on Husbandâ€™s figures for the purpose of equitable apportionment.Â  When equitably apportioning property, the family court may accept one partyâ€™s valuations of marital property over those of the other party.Â  Smith v. Smith, 294 S.C. 194, 198, 363 S.E.2d 404, 407 (Ct. App. 1987).Â  The weight the family court affords the testimony of witnesses, including parties, is within its discretion.Â  Id.Â  There is sufficient evidence in the record to support the family courtâ€™s order adopting Husbandâ€™s valuations.Â Â  Thus, we find no abuse of discretion.Â  
B. Valuation of marital debt Â 
Wife next asserts that the valuation of the partiesâ€™ marital debt was in error.Â  We disagree.
There is a rebuttable presumption that debt incurred by either party prior to marital litigation is marital debt subject to equitable apportionment.Â  Hickum v. Hickum, 320 S.C. 97, 102, 463 S.E.2d 321, 324 (Ct. App. 1995).Â  â€œ[T]he same rules of fairness and equity which apply to the equitable division of marital property also apply to the division of marital debts.â€Â  Id. at 102, 463 S.E.2d at 324.Â  The burden of proving a spouseâ€™s debt as non-marital rests upon the party who makes such an assertion.Â  Id. at 102, 463 S.E.2d at 324.Â  In this case, the burden is on Wife.
The family court found that each party took a certain amount of debt with them at the time of separation.Â  Wife took $16,856, and Husband took $24,000.Â  Wife argues that the evidence supports the amount of her debt, but not the amount of Husbandâ€™s debt.Â  Wife contends $14,430 of the debt was accrued post-separation, and the family court abused its discretion when this amount was included in the marital estate.Â  Husband testified that the entire $24,000 debt was accrued before the parties separated.Â  It was within the family courtâ€™s discretion to accept Husbandâ€™s testimony even though Wife offered conflicting testimony.Â  We find no abuse of discretion.Â  
C. Valuation of time shares
Wife next argues it was error for the court to apportion two time-shares without valuing the property.Â  
Neither party introduced evidence regarding the time-sharesâ€™ value.Â  The family court is not required to value property before equitable apportionment when neither party offered any evidence as to that propertyâ€™s value.Â  â€œA party may not complain to this court that the trial courtâ€™s valuation is unsupported by the evidence without offering proof of value at trial.â€Â  Roe v. Roe, 311 S.C. 471, 479, 429 S.E.2d 830, 836 (Ct. App. 1993).Â  â€œCase law indicates that the family court judge should first attempt an in-kind distribution.â€Â 
Wooten v. Wooten, 358 S.C. 54, 62, 594 S.E.2d 854, 858 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  
The parties obtained two time-shares during the marriage.Â  One was a two-week block of time and the other was for one week.Â  The parties submitted the time-shares for equitable apportionment, but neither party offered any evidence concerning value.Â  The court divided the asset in kind pursuant to the 65%/35% by awarding Husband the two-week time share and Wife the one-week time share.Â  We find there is no abuse of discretion in this decision.Â  
D. Mathematical error
Wife asserts a mathematical error was made when allocating the property among the parties according to the 65%/35% apportionment. Â 
This issue is not preserved for appellate review.Â  Wife did not raise the issue of an error in mathematical calculations to the family court in a post-trial motion.Â  As the issue was not raised to the family court for correction, it is not appropriately before this court on appeal.Â  McDavid, 333 S.C. at 497, 511 S.E.2d at 368-69.Â  
III.Â  RECRIMINATION
Wife argues the family court abused its discretion in granting a divorce on the ground of adultery and assessing the cost of a private investigator against her because she pled the affirmative defense of recrimination in her answer.Â  We find the issue is not preserved for our review.
â€œRecrimination is a defense to an action for divorce if the acts of recrimination charged constitute in themselves a ground for divorce.â€Â  Bakala v. Bakala, 352 S.C. 612, 634, 576 S.E.2d 156, 167 (2003).Â  In order to bar the Husband from receiving a divorce on the ground of adultery, the Wife must have proven at trial that she was entitled to a divorce on a fault ground.Â  Wife asserted the defense of recrimination in her answer and counterclaim, alleging Husband committed adultery.Â  However, Wife offered no evidence at trial concerning adultery on the part of Husband.Â  The only remote reference to adultery in the record is Wifeâ€™s testimony, â€œLee told me that he was getting married.â€Â  This testimony alone is not proof of adultery, and it would not support the defense of recrimination.Â  
Further, Wife failed to argue the defense of recrimination to the family court and failed to raise the courtâ€™s failure to rule on the issue in a post-trial motion.Â  Because the defense of recrimination was not ruled upon by the family court, it is not preserved for our review.Â  McDavid, 333 S.C. at 497, 511 S.E.2d at 368-69.Â  
CONCLUSION
Wife failed to preserve for review the questions of whether the family court erred in: considering Wifeâ€™s post-pendente lite relationship and spending on plastic surgery in equitably dividing the marital estate; awarding Husband 65% of Wifeâ€™s military retirement benefits; computing the amount of the marital estate representing a 65%/35% split; and failing to recognize Wifeâ€™s defense of recrimination.Â  Based on the record, we find the family court considered all the equitable distribution factors and did not abuse its discretion in making a 65%/35% split of the marital estate.Â  The family court further did not abuse its discretion in adopting Husbandâ€™s valuation of the marital estate and marital debts and in failing to place a value on the time shares.Â  Accordingly, the final order of the family court is 
 AFFIRMED.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA

Submitted November 1, 2004 â€“ Filed November 29, 2004

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Michael Dayse, of North Charleston, for Appellant.
Charles S. Goldberg, of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this breach of contract action, Michael Dayse appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order affirming the magistrateâ€™s entry of judgment in favor of St. Lukeâ€™s Reformed Episcopal Church (St. Lukeâ€™s).Â  He contends the circuit court erred in reviewing the magistrateâ€™s decision solely for errors of law and not considering errors of fact.Â  We reverse and remand.[1]
FACTS
St. Lukeâ€™s entered into a contract with Dayse whereby Dayse agreed to perform landscaping, build a wheelchair ramp, and pour concrete for a walkway, curbing, a driveway, and steps.Â  The parties agreed to a contract price of $4,800 with Dayse initially receiving $1,800.Â  Apparently dissatisfied with Dayseâ€™s work, St. Lukeâ€™s fired Dayse and hired someone else to complete the remaining projects.Â  
Subsequently, St. Lukeâ€™s filed a breach of contract action against Dayse in magistrateâ€™s court alleging actual damages in the amount of $3,644.12.Â  The magistrate awarded St. Lukeâ€™s this amount but offset the amount with a credit to Dayse in the amount of $366.Â  The magistrate denied Dayseâ€™s motion for a new trial.
Dayse appealed the magistrateâ€™s decision to the circuit court.Â  After hearing arguments and reviewing the magistrateâ€™s return, the circuit court affirmed the judgment in favor of St. Lukeâ€™s.Â  In a form order, the court stated, â€œthere was no error of law committed.â€Â  In a written order, the court explained as follows:

Appellant appears to be dissatisfied with the findings of fact.Â  His argument did not raise any errors of law commited by the lower court judge . . . .Â  This was a bench trial in which the judge is the trier of the facts and the law.Â  The lower court judge heard the testimony and received exhibits as evidence and concluded that the Plaintiff should be awarded judgment by way of a money judgment due to the poor workmanship of the Defendant.Â  

Dayse appeals the order of the circuit court.
DISCUSSION
Dayse argues the circuit court erred in affirming the decision of the magistrate.Â  He asserts the court applied an incorrect standard of review given the court reviewed the appeal only for errors of law and did not consider errors of fact.Â  We agree.
Section 18-7-170 of the South Carolina Code of Laws governs the standard of review applicable in the instant case.Â  Parks v. Characters Night Club, 345 S.C. 484, 490, 548 S.E.2d 605, 608 (Ct. App. 2001) (recognizing that case originating in magistrateâ€™s court and appealed to circuit court is governed by section 18-7-170).Â  This code section states:

Upon hearing the appeal the appellate court shall give judgment according to the justice of the case, without regard to technical errors and defects which do not affect the merits.Â  In giving judgment the court may affirm or reverse the judgment of the court below, in whole or in part, as to any or all the parties and for errors of law or fact.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 18-7-170 (1985).Â  Section 18-7-170 provides that in an appeal from magistrateâ€™s court in a civil action, the circuit court may make its own findings of fact.Â  Parks, 345 S.C. at 490, 548 S.E.2d at 608; see Vacation Time of Hilton Head Island, Inc. v. Kiwi Corp., 280 S.C. 232, 234, 312 S.E.2d 20, 21 (Ct. App. 1984) (â€œSections 18-7-140 and 18-7-170 give the Circuit Judge sitting in an appellate capacity the ability to make a determination in the same manner as Circuit Courts in trials without a jury and to reverse a judgment for errors of fact even though the Circuit Judge may not have had the opportunity to observe the demeanor of the witnesses.â€); Rogers v. State, 358 S.C. 266, 269 n.1, 594 S.E.2d 278, 279 n.1 (Ct. App. 2004) (distinguishing standards of review in circuit court in criminal and civil appeals from magistrateâ€™s court and noting that the circuit court in a civil appeal may make its own findings of fact). 
In terms of this courtâ€™s standard of review, we â€œwill presume that an affirmance by a Circuit Court of a magistrateâ€™s judgment was made upon the merits where the testimony is sufficient to sustain the judgment of the magistrate and there are no facts that show the affirmance was influenced by an error of law.â€Â  Burns v. Wannamaker, 281 S.C. 352, 357, 315 S.E.2d 179, 182 (Ct. App. 1984), affâ€™d as modified, 288 S.C. 398, 343 S.E.2d 27 (1986).Â  However, â€œthis court will not grant that presumption where . . . it clearly appears that the Circuit Court applied an erroneous standard of review and failed to accord the contested facts the scrutiny which Section 18-7-170 contemplates.â€Â  Id.
Turning to the instant case, we find the circuit court applied an erroneous standard of review.Â  As evident by the form order, the circuit court only reviewed the magistrateâ€™s decision for errors of law.Â  Although the court subsequently issued a written order, this order did not cure the error.Â  In the final order, the court again referenced Dayseâ€™s failure to raise â€œany errors of law.â€Â  Moreover, instead of making its own findings of fact, the court deferred to the magistrateâ€™s findings by stating the magistrate was â€œthe trier of the facts and the law.â€Â  Because the circuit court applied an erroneous standard of review and failed to properly consider the disputed facts pursuant to section 18-7-170, we reverse the decision of the circuit court and remand the case for a determination consistent with this opinion.
 REVERSED AND REMANDED. 
HUFF, KITTREDGE, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

[1] Â Â Because oral argument would not aid the court in resolving the issue on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
